b'"I find that many times I'm in such a rush to get to the top of a hike/mountain to take photos, that I often don't slow down and enjoy all the photos I could take along the way. This photo and hike reminded me to slow down and enjoy the ride, which I feel like can apply to a lot of things in life!" :fallen_leaf: :mountain_selector: Thank you for sharing your #CanonMemories with us, @jkayephotography!
Camera: #Canon EOS 7D Mark II
Lens: Canon EF-S 10-22mm f/3.5-4.5 USM

b'Photo by @paulzizkaphoto "Overlap of seasons. Colourful avalanche slopes escape the first snowfall of the season in fire-ravaged Kootenay National Park, British Columbia, Canada. This was shot around sunset time, when in the past I would have likely pulled out the tripod in order to ensure image sharpness. How nice to be handholding for an extra 30 minutes or so around sunset and sunrise due to the incredible image stabilization built into the 70-200."

:camera_with_flash:: #Canon EOS R5
Lens: RF70-200mm F4 L IS USM'

b'"My girlfriend and I were sitting by Indian Lake, in New York, eating our lunch, when a mama duck came out, asking for food. She took one bite of a cracker and abruptly left. A few seconds later, all of her babies came rushing out, squeaking and stumbling over each other to find the nice people their mother just told them about." :duck:Thank you for sharing your #CanonMemories with us, @andreweatworld!
Camera: #Canon EOS 5D Mark IV

b'Welcome back to another episode of #LensdayWednesday, where each week we will be highlighting the wide range of Canon lenses. \n\nIn this episode, Marketing Specialist Tony Tran (@tonytran.photography), goes over Canon\xe2\x80\x99s new bright prime lens from the EOS R series lineup, the RF50mm F1.8 STM. Stay tuned as Tony shares why the RF50mm F1.8 STM is a must-have in his camera bag, or pocket. #LearnwithCanon #TeamCanon'

b'Check out what's in #CanonExplorerOfLight @jenwuphoto's gear bag! 

"What\xe2\x80\x99s in my bag? When I go on a photography trip, I take different gear depending on the subjects I am photographing!

For landscape photography I take both camera bodies EOS 5D Mark IV and EOS 5DS R. I will take my three core lenses: EF 16-35mm f/4L IS USM, the EF 24-70mm f/2.8L II USM and the EF 70-200mm f/2.8L IS II USM. Then depending on the location, I will pick one or two others for a different perspective, such as the EF 14mm f/2.8L II USM, EF 11-24mm f/4L USM, TS-E 17mm f/4L tilt-shift, TS-E 24mm f/3.5L tilt-shift or EF 180mm f/3.5L Macro USM. For night photography adventures, I only bring the EOS 5D Mark IV camera bodies and swap out the 16-35mm f/4 for a 16-35 f/2.8 that I will use for night and daytime landscapes. Plus I will bring the EF 24mm f/1.4L II USM, perhaps the EF 14mm f/2.8L II USM. Also, a battery grip for extended battery life to use for time-lapse and circular star trails. For wildlife, I will bring the EF 24-70mm f/2.8L II USM, EF 100-400mm f/4.5-5.6L IS II USM, EF 200-400mm f/4L USM Extender 1.4x and Extender EF 1.4x III. I bring the EOS 5D Mark IV body with grip and/or EOS-1D X Mark III."

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @peter_hurley "I had just finished a shoot at @robertmerrillstudio and Robert was roaming around, so I jumped at the chance to get a new headshot of this ruggedly handsome character. We go way back to our modeling days in NYC and when I closed down my LA studio he graciously let me shoot in his. It had been a while since I last photographed him and in 5 minutes we had a slew of incredible images. This one stood out to me the most."

:camera_with_flash: #Canon EOS R
Lens: EF 70-200mm f/4L USM'

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @peter_hurley "I absolutely love working with @evypoumpouras! It\xe2\x80\x99s great when clients have a clear vision for their brand and take it upon themselves to continually create new content on a regular basis to promote it. Over the years Evy and I have been working consistently together to do just that. For this image I wanted to not only convey her strength through the expression, but capture a clean black and white horizontal image that was shot wide on purpose to emphasize the graphic nature of the chair that we used as a prop."

:camera_with_flash: #Canon EOS R5
Lens: RF 15-35mm F2.8 L IS USM'

b'#CanonExplorerOfLight @peter_hurley is taking over our page today! "The connection between the photographer and subject is paramount. For me it\xe2\x80\x99s everything and I know the images are created through that rapport. So when I was developing a new background as well as lights and I needed to test them out, I was so glad to have @chloelittlewing help me. We\xe2\x80\x99d been working together for years and we\xe2\x80\x99ve always had that special connection that is the foundation for something great to happen."

:camera_with_flash: #Canon EOS 5D Mark III
Lens: EF 100mm f/2.8L Macro IS USM'

b'Swipe to learn how @parker_burkett captured this photo "The human element, is one of my favorite additions to a photo. Adding a person\'s point of view or photographing someone in the distance can add so much to a photo, for aesthetics as well as for scale, but also to make you feel as though you are actually there. Those could be your legs sitting on the edge of a beautiful vista. I always love to hear people\xe2\x80\x99s thoughts on this type of photography. \n\nDoes this photo make you feel immersed in the crisp fall air and breathtaking sight in front of you?\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @lindsayadler_photo "What happens when you mix red, green and blue light? If you know about additive color you know it makes white! 

This extraordinarily colorful image was created in the studio using 3 strobes and my knowledge of color! 

I remember back in middle school when my teacher overlapped 3 projectors (red, green, blue) to show how we could create RGB, CMY, and white light depending on how we positioned the colors. At the time I never realized how this would end up leading to an amazing photographic technique decades later! I guess the lesson is pay attention in school? Or maybe it is\xe2\x80\xa6 don\xe2\x80\x99t be afraid to experiment in the studio! :D 

For this shot my main light was a Magnum reflector (hard light modifier) with a red gel and two zoom reflectors (one green and one blue) offset below my subject. Of course the incredible hair and makeup helped to make this shot even more eye-catching! 

I captured this with my Canon EOS R and my RF 24-105mm F4 lens. I love this lens because it is so versatile -- I can quickly change between a full length shot and a closeup beautiful crop like this one in a snap!"'

b'Early Sunday strolls through an orange haze :fallen_leaf:

:camera_with_flash:  #Canon EOS 5D Mark II

b'Swipe to learn how\xc2\xa0@beholdingeye\xc2\xa0captured this photo \xe2\x80\x9cPhotography is all about being able to adapt. On our Canon Road Trip\xc2\xa0@parker_burkett\xc2\xa0and I were thrown the ultimate curve ball while we encountered a winter storm in the beginning of autumn. In that moment we felt that the morning shoot was ruined, but we were welcomed by some most unexpected conditions on our way back down the mountain, which allowed us to capture some truly unique images.\n\nWhat\xe2\x80\x99s been your most unique or unexpected weather conditions to shoot in?\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'"This was hands down my favorite memory of 2020. The day started out waking up in the back of my car, not sure what I was going to do that day. Turns out, a fellow photographer (that I had never met in person) was in the same area shooting. We met up for pancakes at the gas station (don't laugh, they were amazing)! We hiked, got caught in a crazy summer rainstorm, caught a rainbow form over Tioga Pass, watched lightning over Mono Lake, and even saw some deer and bald eagles. Oh...and it ended with this storm clearing, magnificent sunset. Now that's a pretty good day." :red_heart_selector: :orange_heart: :yellow_heart: Thank you for sharing your #CanonMemories with us, @lahorstman!
Camera: #Canon EOS 5D Mark IV
Lens: Canon EF 24-70mm f/2.8L II USM 
Have a photo and memory you're thankful for? Submit them at canon.us/canonmemories'

b'Find out what's in #CanonExplorerOfLight @stephenjohnsonphoto's gear bag! "My camera bag has moving parts depending on the trip and agenda. It also has to have a core set of tools that are always needed. Two camera bodies are a good idea, at this point one for the highest resolution, the EOS 5DS R, and one for the highest ISO capability, usually now the EOS R5. I very rarely carry all of my lenses, but always have a 24-105mm with Macro capability, a 100-400mm zoom and now the RF600mm. 

I consider a macro option a constant, so carry a close focusing lens and extension tube.

As color accuracy is very important to me, I keep the ColorChecker Passport with me.

Lens cleaning tools are a constant, as well as focusing aids like a screen magnifier. My green laser helps by creating a sharp focusing point at night. My trigger trips the shutter based on a millisecond IR pulse it detects just as the lightning flashes. My gooseneck clamp allows me to very gently hold some plants in place for some breeze resistance. 

With the very high-quality video options now built-in to most cameras, I am frequently recording Earth in motion video. But it is also true that I meet interesting people with stories to tell, as well as my own, so wireless and corded external microphones are in my bag, as well as headphones to monitor the sound.

There is a variable Neutral Density filter in the bag as well as a polarizer, but it is rarely used.

My Canon GPS needs AA batteries, and my wireless microphone takes 9 volt cells so extras of both are always along.

My business cards, a hat, medical kit, sunscreen and water are always with me.

My tripod is omni-present but way too big for my camera bag."'

b'Watch to learn how @beholdingeye captured his favorite photo on the Canon Road Trip.
\xc2\xa0
"The lighting was optimal for shooting waterfalls in the gorge this day; mostly cloudy with filtered light. With these conditions, I used my 4 stop neutral density filter paired with a polarizing filter. Filters allow the photographer to achieve the desired effect they are envisioning. By using a neutral density filter I could increase my shutter speed to smooth out the water, and cut through the glare on top of the water at the same time.
\xc2\xa0
Do you use filters to work around difficult light?\xe2\x80\x9c'

b'Swipe to learn how @parker_burkett captured this photo "Getting the shot is half the fun! I achieved my final photo by photographing portrait, low, and slow. When photographing, always do your best to take multiple compositions, multiple shutter speeds and try something new! If you normally shoot with your tripod fully extended, try using only one leg length and get low to the ground. You can also use filters to slow your shutter speed down and test out different speeds. I shoot waterfalls at 1.3-1.6 seconds for silky smooth, detailed water. I shoot water moving through rocks at 1/3 or 1/4 of a second to show motion, with a little bit of silk. What are your favorite waterfall settings?"'

b'"This is Titan, my Siberian Husky, at Siloam Springs State Park, a place that will forever be my favorite location. I grew up camping in this very scenic area, and over the years it's become less and less busy\xe2\x80\x94almost seeming like a ghost town. But here\xe2\x80\x99s to hoping this beautiful park never closes its gates." :dog::national_park_selector: Thank you for sharing your #CanonMemories with us, @titanandrosie!

b'#BehindTheShot with #CanonExplorerOfLight @charlesglatzer "I love taking intimate portraits of wildlife. With this image, the wider focal length and low angle provides an intimate perspective. Keeping the camera level helps avoid distortion. 
While the steam from the hot spring sets a wonderful mood and provides sense of context, it will degrade subject sharpness. The wider angle lens and close proximity to the animal negated the fog between us, allowing me to render the subject tack sharp.

Most wild animals do not like direct eye contact, as it is considered antagonistic. This is especially true when you are close to the animal. Learned the hard way, wink." 

:camera_with_flash: : #Canon EOS-1D X Mark II 
Lens: EF 24-70mm f/2.8L USM'

b'"The story behind this photo, as is often the case, is that it wasn't at all what I had in mind when I originally set out on this very early morning in October. All I was hoping for was a moon setting at the end of this often photographed curvy road, but as luck would have it, the lighting when I first arrived turned out to be the star of the morning. My original composition was a bust, but I ended up with this as one of my personal favorite photos ever. If I've learned anything about photography, it is that the more effort you put into it, the more luck you will have." :motorway_selector::sun_selector: Thank you for sharing your #CanonMemories with us, @masseyfoto
Camera: #Canon EOS 7D Mark II
Lens: EF-S 18-135 MM F/3.5-5.6 IS STM

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @creativesoulphoto "When photographing models with darker skin tones we love using light to shape and enhance their skin tones rather than having it look too washed out. For this shot, we decided to slightly underexpose so that we maintain the richness in her skin. We used a Profoto B10+ light on a large octabox slightly above the model. Our Canon EF 24-70mm f/2.8L II USM lens allowed us to get a variety of frames and options. In post processing we used adjustment layers to enhance the skin even more and bring out the vibrancy to finish off the image."

:camera_with_flash: #Canon EOS 5D Mark III
Lens: EF 24-70mm f/2.8L II USM

Model: @nevaeh_camara
Hair: @ancestralstrands 
Body Art/Floral Piece: @mirage_magic'

b'Photo by @blair.bunting \xe2\x80\x9cThe most important part of learning photography is embracing your mistakes. I went to this location (a bridge about an hour from my house) on six different occasions to make this piece. The first five times I got an image, but not the one that existed in my mind. However, I learned and planned how I would improve the next time and tried my hardest to implement those changes. While I wanted to shoot this train at 35mm, at the end of the day 28mm on the RF 28-70mm F2 L USM felt more immersive and proved to be the solution I needed.\xe2\x80\x9d

:camera_with_flash:  #Canon EOS R
Lens: RF 28-70mm F2 L USM'

b'Find out what's in #CanonExplorerOfLight @simonbruty's gear bag! "Photographing golf is all about trying to find a balance between too much gear or not enough. My standard gear generally tends to be one long lens either a 400mm or 600mm, 70-200mm and one short zoom. I will change the gear set up depending on the location of the event. You don't want to be over lensed and miss any of the emotion."

b'Photo by @mcteams3842 \xe2\x80\x9cServing in the military requires exceptional professionalism, perseverance, and devotion to honor, duty, and country\xe2\x80\x94a self-sacrifice where you put others before you. Having this level of pride and commitment to others is a unique and uncommon trait. Basic Underwater Demolition/SEAL (BUD/S) training is designed to find and develop operators of the strongest character and never quit mindset to accomplish the mission. Becoming a SEAL requires intensive training, dedication, courage, and commitment to being an operator in the United States military. With an average failure rate of 80%, few are able to overcome the physical and mental challenges. The men who succeed work alongside the bravest men and women who have dedicated themselves to putting country before self. Becoming a Navy SEAL is believing you can make the impossible possible and become more that what you thought you could achieve. I was honored to be the only SEAL to photograph this training and to show from my perspective\xe2\x80\x94having lived this experience\xe2\x80\x94how far students are willing to push themselves to have the privilege of defending our freedoms.
 
In this image: One of the hardest elemental conditions at BUD/S training is adapting to the cold. Candidates will be wet and covered with sand, day and night. Nonstop shivering, numb hands, and cold feet are a constant. It\xe2\x80\x99s the mental war between your ears that will allow you to either move on or succumb to weakness. Being cold and uncomfortable develops the never quit attitude that is the hallmark of being a Navy SEAL. You have to be comfortable being uncomfortable.\xe2\x80\x9d 

We\xe2\x80\x99re thankful for the sacrifice and bravery of all who have served and continue to serve. #VeteransDay :United_States:
 
:camera_with_flash: Canon EOS 5D Mark III
Lens: EF 100-400mm f/4.5-5.6L IS USM'

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @ricksammonphotography "Iceland\xe2\x80\x99s famous glacier lagoon \xe2\x80\x93 filled with breathtaking blue, white and clear ice formations \xe2\x80\x93 is a photographer\xe2\x80\x99s paradise. The key when photographing in situations like this is to \xe2\x80\x98cut the clutter,' in other words, compose a picture with a main subject or subjects. Tip: Think like a painter: think what you want to include on your \xe2\x80\x98canvas\xe2\x80\x99 (image sensor) and what you don\xe2\x80\x99t want to include."

:camera_with_flash:  #Canon EOS 5DS
Lens: EF 24-105mm f/4L IS USM'

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @ricksammonphotography "Before I left home for Sri Lanka, I set several photographic goals, one being to get a picture of the famous stick fisherman at sunset. After searching for a week, I finally found my photo op. The light was perfect. I was in the right place, finally, at the right time \xe2\x80\x93 and I got my shot. Tip: Set a goal, in your photography and in your life."

:camera_with_flash:  #Canon EOS 5D Mark IV
Lens: EF 24-105mm f/4L IS USM'

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @ricksammonphotography "Leopards are one of my favorite photo safari subjects. They are also some of the most elusive. Our guide spotted this wonderful animal that was hiding in the bushes. A moment later, the leopard came out of hiding, looked directly at me and sat down, perhaps contemplating his next meal. I grabbed my camera and took a quick photo before he scooted back into the darkness of the bushes. Tip: Try to photograph at a subject\xe2\x80\x99s eye level to get that eye-to-eye feeling."

:camera_with_flash:  #Canon EOS 5D Mark III
Lens: EF 70-300mm f/4-5.6L IS USM'

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @ricksammonphotography "I photographed these cormorant fishermen before sunrise on the Li River in Guilin, China. My goal was to capture the mood and feeling of the moment, as mood matters most in photography \xe2\x80\x93 as well as in other forms. Tip: When photographing more than one subject, compose your photograph so that you have separation between/among the subjects \xe2\x80\x93 so that individual subjects stand out in the frame."

:camera_with_flash:  #Canon EOS 5D Mark IV
Lens: EF 24-70mm f/2.8L II USM'

b'#CanonExplorerOfLight @ricksammonphotography is taking over today! "I photographed this mommy gentoo penguin and her chick in Antarctica. As a wildlife photographer, I often apply human traits to animals, which is called anthropomorphism. With that thought in mind, 'Motherly Love' is the only title I can give to this image. Tip: When photographing wildlife, look for and capture gesture."

:camera_with_flash:  #Canon EOS R
Lens: EF 100-400mm f/4.5-5.6L IS II USM'

b'Photo by @paulzizkaphoto "Life and death on the banks of the North Saskatchewan River. Riverside evergreen trees glow in the morning sun while their higher counterparts offer a much starker scene. Warden Lake fire area, Alberta, Canada. This was one of those situations when the light was changing extremely fast, and so I was thrilled to be able to quickly gather a few images of this distant scene without having to rely on a tripod or carry bulky gear. The astonishingly light EOS R5 and RF70-200mm F4 L IS USM combo is truly the way to go for those short-lived, intimate landscape scenes."'

b'#BehindTheShot with #CanonExplorerOfLight @tylerstableford "Of all the images I have captured as an adventure photographer and filmmaker, this shot was one of the hardest to pull off! The image is part of my fine-art series \xe2\x80\x9cInto The Deep\xe2\x80\x9d with Ashley Mosher (@ashleymosher) and whale sharks in the Caribbean waters of Mexico. For the images to succeed emotionally, Ashley needed to be a part of the fathomless deep, meeting the whale shark from below. To start, Ashley had to swim over to, and in front of, a moving whale shark; and then draw a big breath and plunge underwater. She swam deep to position herself below the shark \xe2\x80\x94 all without a mask, snorkel or fins. And only then could she begin the graceful dance. She arced and twirled alongside the shark until her searing lungs forced her to the surface, gasping. We failed. A lot. At times, getting a perfectly choreographed shot seemed impossible.
 
With snorkeling gear, I was limited in my time underwater, too. I kicked hard to swim through the backwash behind the shark\xe2\x80\x99s powerful tail fin \xe2\x80\x94 it was here that the shark looked most dramatic through the 14mm lens. Ashley gave everything she had to the shoot. We spent over 4 hours in the water, all while drifting amongst the most stunning creatures we have ever encountered. And, yes \xe2\x80\x94 we were blessed with several magical images. The photos in this series are the real moment, no compositing. Big thanks to Ashley, and to Kate Rolston (@kate_rolston) for additional imagery and inspiration. 

Whale sharks, like other species of sharks, are endangered and need our support. Sharks populations have been reduced by diminished habitat and by high prices for their fins. I hope this post helps create interest in this wonderful species." 

:camera_with_flash: #Canon EOS 5D Mark III
Lens: EF 14mm f/2.8L II USM'

b'\xe2\x80\x9cI am happiest in, by, and around the water. It's a place of serenity, peace and contemplation. More than anything, its the never-ending motion to the sea and the sounds that accompany that motion that I seek refuge in. When I am photographing the water, I am chasing an image that can adequately articulate my relationship to the ocean. I hope the same peace and wonder washes over those who see my photography." :water_wave: Thank you for sharing your #CanonMemories with us, @dannywimages. 
Camera: #Canon EOS 5D Mark IV

b'Photo by @irenerudnykphoto "In 2011, I bought my first full frame prime lens, it was the EF 50mm f/1.8. It was all I could afford after spending my savings on the EOS 5D Mark II. I absolutely loved this lens and created some of my favorite early work with it. I am so excited to now photograph some portraits with its improved version 9 years later :) I recommend the RF50mm F1.8 STM lens for anyone who is trying to get into portrait photography. It's a great 'starting out' lens for many reasons. Its focal length is similar to what our human eye sees and is very universal - perfect for both indoor and outdoor photoshoots!"

b'Photo by @beholdingeye "As photographers, preparation is key. But what happens when you can\xe2\x80\x99t prepare?

This was the case when @parker_burkett and I went searching for the only wild elk herd east of the Mississippi on our Canon Road Trip. We knew one thing, in the area of Benezette, PA there are elk, and that there were 3-4 prime spots to maybe see them.

So we packed up the gear and set out on a chilly, rainy morning to see what we could find. That day I shot with my Canon EOS R5 and the RF100-500mm f/4.5-7.1 L USM lens. I got set up on my tripod, found my frame, and waited. You can imagine my surprise when a bull emerged from behind a hill, strutted across the field and struck this majestic pose!

As photographers, we have few precious moments when all things align to capture 'the perfect photo' we had come for. What was your perfectly unplanned moment?"

:camera_with_flash: #Canon EOS R5
Lens: RF100-500mm F4.5-7.1 L IS USM'

Schwabacher Landing is an iconic spot to photograph the Tetons with reflection in the still water of the Snake river. The Tetons' ever-changing moods require you to keep your eye to the viewfinder. The early morning alpine glow was short lived, lasting only a few brief minutes during an opening in the cloudy sky."

b'Photo by @nathanleeallen "It\xe2\x80\x99s crazy how on a trip, plans can change in a blink of an eye. We had actually planned to shoot another pond the morning of this shot and drove by this one on the way. It looked perfectly still and glassy, with the fall foliage mirrored in the water and the morning mist blanking the pond's surface. We assumed the other pond would look the same.

However, when we got to the pond we had originally planned for, conditions were super choppy and windy, so we all decided to hightail it back to the other pond, and I\xe2\x80\x99m so glad we did. The shots turned out fantastic and the foliage around the pond was so wonderful to shoot. Not ashamed at all, but I took over 1000 images that morning.

Now, how did I capture this shot, what gear did I use, and what were my camera settings? I used the new @canonusa EOS R6 full-frame mirrorless camera with the Canon RF 70-200mm f/2.8L IS USM lens to capture this shot. The fast Dual Pixel CMOS of the EOS R6 combined with RF 70-200mm f/2.8 made this shot possible and allowed me to compress my subject on the lake and capture a sharp image, even when she was moving quickly throughout the water (Thanks, @eyeofshe, I know it was cold out there)."

 #eosr6 #cocreatewithcanon #canonusa'

b'Photo by @parker_burkett \xe2\x80\x9cBright fall colors mixed with the undeniable beauty of a waterfall are one of life's most simple pleasures. On our Canon Road Trip, Paul (@beholdingeye) and I had such an incredible time hiking through some of the most beautiful locations, and this was one of my favorites. The busy, colorful textures of a forest during fall in contrast with the silky smooth water seamlessly cascading through the scene is a sight to behold. Lost in our craft, like two kids in a candy store of compositions, we could have spent the whole day looking for shots just like these. The northeast truly has some of the most beautiful fall colors in the country.  Where did you choose to shoot this fall?"

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @Onnevanderwal "This image was my final selection in the challenge against famed surfing photographer @zaknoyle.

I was fortunate that the owner of Wild Horses, a W class 76ft ocean going yacht, was headed out to sea. I shot Wild Horses from my 25ft chase boat ONNEsignment using the Canon EOS R5 with the RF 15-35 F2.8L IS USM lens in the @aquatech_imagingsolutions Edge housing, which was a specially designed waterproof housing for the EOS R5 for the 'in the spray and waves shot.' This housing enabled me to get the camera right on the water\xe2\x80\x99s surface. I was firing away blindly as the camera was too low to get my eye behind the viewfinder and so decided to set the shutter actuation to 12 fps.

The advantage of being an inch or two above the surface of the ocean (and at times in it) with a wide angle lens set at 19mm and F20 with a slow shutter speed of 1/20th is that it looks like you are really flying along yet the sailboat is tack sharp due to the chase boat and the sailboat doing exactly the same speed, all that\xe2\x80\x99s moving in the image is the water. I preset the focus to 36 inches and switched off the autofocus so that the camera never hunted and tried to focus on the drops of water on the dome port or the moving ocean waves. I set the ISO to 1000 as it was an overcast day and wanted to have a ton of depth of field so set the aperture at F20 and a shutter speed of 1/20th to show the motion in the water. I also set the exposure compensation to +.7 due to the fact that the lens was looking at a lot of bright grey sky. If I did not overcompensate the sails, the boat would have been too dark. Had it been a blue sky with sunshine this compensation would not have been necessary. So, there you have it, the story behind the shot. I hope you like it. Oh, and yes I got completely soaked shooting this shot but the camera stayed as dry as a bone!"'

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @bobanddawn_inthewild "I love photographing on location and the challenges it presents. That's what I do as a photographer, evaluate the scene before me, and think of the best possible way to create a photograph, lighting to create the mood and help tell the story. This photograph was taken in the theater district of Chicago. The alleyway is painted with murals and play posters. Both Erica and Sir are actors and this is part of their story. 

I chose to use dramatic lighting to emulate stage lighting. I used two EL-1 Speedlites. The Main light is an EL-1 in Group A, in ETTL, with a MagMod MagBeam with a circle mask giving that spotlight effect. The second EL-1 was held by Sir facing the wall with a MagMod Magsphere in Group B, manual mode 1/8th power flash output. The new modeling light allowed me to focus and dial in the direction and height of the main light. I did the same with the modeling light in Group B to see how that Speedlite would eliminate the mural. 

The new features of the EL-1 allow me to work faster and take less time fussing with the gear and more time interacting with the couple improving the energy and quality of the photographs I'm creating."'

"Photographing birds is my hobby, and I always enjoy seeing White Great Egrets in mating mode when a patch of skin on their face turns bright green. During that period they also grow long plumes called aigrettes from their back. Took this in Malibu at a known nesting site. In the late 19th century the fancy-looking aigrettes were prized for ladies\xe2\x80\x99 hats, and led to the demise of a lot of egrets. Fortunately, public reaction and government intervention caused the fad to end, saving the Egrets from possible extinction."

b'"For as long as I can remember I had always wanted to capture a foggy morning with fall foliage, but with fog being so unpredictable, it was always the shot I never seemed to get. Every time I went to Shenandoah I would get perfectly clear skies and not even a hint of fog. Last fall I planned a day trip with a friend to capture a beautiful sunrise with fall color. I woke up at 4:15am, drove out to Shenandoah and noticed the closer I got to the mountains, the sky didn't seem so clear like the weather had predicted. When the sun came up, there was no colorful sunrise like I expected to capture, but instead my wonderful fall foggy morning scene that I had always dreamed of capturing! b'I think one of my favorite things to photograph is Lake Tahoe when the weather isn't all calm and blue skies. When storm clouds pour over the mountains and the winds whip up the water in the lake, it can make for some great opportunities. This one is now a new favorite memory, having been out to shoot the sunset for the first time in a long time. The sunlight was interspersed by the clouds, moving in shafts of light across the lake and hitting the eastern shore of Tahoe every few minutes. I was lucky enough that the wind had picked up enough energy to create some wave action on the shore while the sunlight illuminated the trees that lined the edge of the lake." :cloud_with_lightning_selector: Thank you for sharing your #CanonMemories with us, @moralvictory.

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @49ersofficialphotog "I call this image 'Leo the Lion' as he gave me the best portrait that I had captured during my trip. The way it works is you are on a game drive in a large open jeep and once you spot an animal, we will pull over, shut off the engine and watch the animals in their environment. You are instructed to never stand up tall in the vehicle as this will make the animals nervous and want to approach. This was hard for me as I wanted to stand so many times. For this image you can see green colors in the background and how strong and majestic the lion looks in this photograph. This is one of my favorites." 

:camera_with_flash:  #Canon EOS 7D
Lens: EF 70-200mm f/2.8L IS II USM'

Each day you will come upon new animals as you drive inside the game reserve. This day I was able to capture this leopard in the brushes looking for his next animal to prey on. b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @bobanddawn_inthewild "Sunset along the shore of Lake Michigan with the Chicago skyline as the backdrop takes my breath away. The new flagship Speedlite EL-1 with its improved quality of light, built-in fan to keep the flash from over heating and new rechargeable battery allow me to capture moments as they unfold. I am no longer waiting for the flash to recharge, the EL-1 has 0.9 second recycle at full power with an improved 335 full power flashes between recharges. \n\nThis lifestyle engagement session of Erica and Sir demanded the fast recycle time. The waves were washing over the sidewalk and my goal was to create a photograph that reelects the engird of the couple. To capture this photograph I used three EL-1 Speedlites grouped together all in Group A, I triggered the Speedlites using the STE3 Speedlite Transmitter in ETTL mode. I often group three Speedlites together using the Westcott Triple Threat for increased flash performance. The EL-1s grouped this way performed like a studio strobe on location. The EOS R5 with eye/face/head detection enabled provided the perfect exposure as the ambient light was rapidly changing."'

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @bobanddawn_inthewild "Speedlites may be small in size, but they have huge potential! The power and possibilities of using Speedlites is endless, I can do more with more lights verses more light. What I mean by that, is I would rather be on location with five Speedlites verses one 500 watt second strobe!

I wanted to create a dynamic portrait of Reggie Roberts, he's a body builder and athlete. I used three EL-1 Speedlites and three 600EX RT Speedlites to create this portrait. The new and improved ETTL in conjunction with eye/face/head detection has greatly improved the consistency of ETTL Flash Exposure. Let me not forget to mention my new favorite feature, Flash Exposure Memory! When active in the Personal Function #5, you can capture a photograph, review the image, then lock in the flash exposure settings by selecting all or each individual group, and selecting Manual. The exact flash power output is given for all or each individual group. I used Groups mode from the EL-1 Sender, but it was not contributing light to the scene. This is a mix of ETTL and Manual flash modes. Remember the Sender is always in Group A, it's de-active. The Main light is an EL-1 in Group B in ETTL, shaped with a Westcott Rapid Box Beauty Dish. I used 4'x8' black foam core board and cut 1 1/2" slats, covered them with diffusion paper, backlighting the scene with three 600EX RT Speedlites in Group C, Manual mode at 1/2 power bounced into a Westcott 7' silver parabolic umbrella. I grouped the three 600s for more flash output and improved recycle time. I used canned atmosphere to create the haze in the scene and use 4500* Kelvin Color Temperature for the overall cool tone of the portrait.

The new rechargeable Li-on battery utilizing the current LC-E6 battery charger has improved recycle time, I no longer will need to use the high voltage external battery pack to keep up the high energy style of how I shoot."'

b'The new Speedlite EL-1 is the perfect addition to your camera bag. Small in size but large in quality, with its new Powerful Rechargeable Li-ion battery, you can count on it to be there for you throughout your entire photoshoot.'

b'Photo by @nataliekeyssar "I returned to the US from abroad in mid March, anxious to get back to New York to be close to my family as the world suddenly became cloaked in uncertainty. A few days later, it began to dawn on me that I had also flown into the epicenter of the crisis. I can\xe2\x80\x99t really describe the fear and profound sadness of documenting my unstoppable city grind to a halt as we lost thousands of our neighbors, but working through the peak gave me a sense of purpose and allowed me to learn from the doctors, nurses, and essential workers who were and are true heroes for all of us. I photographed retired nurse Laura Benson. She had stepped up to volunteer as a nurse at a daycare for healthcare workers so they could go to work and battle the virus. Photographing is tough when we can\xe2\x80\x99t get close, so I\xe2\x80\x99ve relied a lot on shooting through windows to create a sense of intimacy and capture these somber times without putting myself or others at risk. Laura had that calm, no-nonsense, reassuring presence that so many great nurses do, and her strength and determination really inspired me. Thank you Laura, and thank you to all our essential workers!"

b'Photo by @nataliekeyssar "In my ongoing project, Heaven\xe2\x80\x99s Back Yard, I\xe2\x80\x99ve been documenting Robeson County, North Carolina. I grew up in NC, and it's meant a great deal to me to be able to focus on a place so close to home when so much of my work has been abroad for many years. Robeson is a really beautiful, complicated, diverse place that\xe2\x80\x99s taught me a lot. Tragically, since I\xe2\x80\x99ve been working there, its been hit by two '100 year' hurricanes, that each time resulted in catastrophic flooding all over the county, including in the county seat of Lumberton. Many families in Lumberton were already struggling, and the flooding has been absolutely devastating. I photographed the Lumberton High School JV football team at one of their first practices after the second storm, Hurricane Florence, had devastated their community. At the end of practice, they knelt to pray, and I was moved by this moment of faith and resilience from a group of kids who have already been through way too much in their young lives. These days I look at this picture, and think about what a luxury it was to be able to put your hand on your teammates shoulder to pray."

b'Find out what's in #CanonExplorerOfLight @georgelepp's gear bag! "Now that I\xe2\x80\x99ve adopted Canon\xe2\x80\x99s new mirrorless system, I\xe2\x80\x99m traveling light! All the gear I need for working in the field fits into a fairly small (22L) photo backpack. As I hike about, seeking to photograph wild birds and mammals and their scenic environments, I am ready for anything with this setup. Typically I\xe2\x80\x99ve got the EOS R5 mirrorless body and the RF100-500mm F4.5-7.1 L IS USM lens, and the RF1.4X extender (700mm) in hand. For wide-angles, I have the EF24-105mm f/4L II, and at the longest reach I have the RF800mm F11 IS STM; with the option of adding the RF2x Extender, I can get to 1600mm @ f/22. That covers a pretty extensive range and almost everything in-between. Every one of these lightweight and compact combinations is hand-holdable thanks to great in-body and/or in-lens image stabilization. 

Here is the list of everything that\xe2\x80\x99s in the bag, keyed to the numbered items in the photograph.

1.	Canon EOS R5 camera body
2.	Canon RF100-500mm F4.5-7.1 L IS USM
3.	Canon RF800mm F11 IS STM
4.	Canon EF24-105mm f/4L IS USM
5.	Canon Drop-In Filter Mount Adapter EF-EOS R
5A. Polarizing Filter for Mount Adapter
5B. Variable Neutral Density Filter for Mount Adapter
6.	Canon RF1.4x Extender
7.	Canon RF2x Extender
8.	Canon Electronic Cable Release that fits EOS R5
9.	Extra Hoodman memory cards (CF Express and SDXC II 2000X)
10.	Canon LP-E6NH Batteries (I carry 4, one is in the camera)

I have other setups for macro or landscape, but that\xe2\x80\x99s another bag story."'

b'#BehindTheShot with #CanonExplorerOfLight @ricksammonphotography "In action wildlife photography, the key to getting a good shot is to get the head and eye in sharp focus. If the other parts of the body, such as the wings of a bird, are blurred, that\xe2\x80\x99s okay \xe2\x80\x93 because that motion-blur adds a sense of movement to a still image. 

To get this shot of a puffin in the Faroe Islands flying directly toward me (my goal), I noted the direction in which the birds were taking off. I moved into position, laid down on my belly, and aimed my EOS R with my Canon 100-400mm lens toward a group of puffins that were landing and taking off. I began shooting \xe2\x80\x93 extra wide, with lots of space around a puffin so that the wings and feet would not be cut off in my final image. My camera was set to the highest frame rate (5 fps in the AI Servo mode) to capture subtle differences in the animal's movement. I set the focus to AI Servo (focus tracking, which tracks a moving subject right up to the moment of exposure). 

Although I was photographing fast-paced action, I was shooting in the Av (aperture priority) mode, as I always do, adjusting the aperture to get a shutter speed of 1/1000th of a second, which I found is fast enough to \xe2\x80\x98freeze\xe2\x80\x99 most birds in flight (except for the wings of some super-fast moving birds). After taking a few shots, and zooming in on them on my camera\xe2\x80\x99s LCD monitor, I knew I had achieved my goal and had at least one \xe2\x80\x98keeper.' 

The moral of this story: Set a goal, learn about animal behavior, and use AI Servo focus/High Frame Rate when photographing super-fast moving subjects."

Camera: #Canon EOS R
Lens: EF 100-400mm f/4.5-5.6L IS II USM
Aperture: f/19
ISO: 400
Shutter Speed: 1/1000 sec
Focal Length: 255mm'

b'Photos by @nataliekeyssar "By late May I had been documenting the devastating effects of the pandemic in New York for 3 months, when I got an assignment to photograph Richard Moses, an 89 year old Brooklynite who had survived COVID19, and Linda Moses, his devoted wife of 37 years. The high risk to elderly people has been particularly scary and painful for all of us I think, so I was moved by the chance to photograph this uplifting story of an elderly couple who had made it through and was going on their afternoon walk in Brooklyn Heights. I\xe2\x80\x99m not sure I\xe2\x80\x99ve ever met such kind, youthful, light-hearted people. Just setting up the shoot on the phone with Linda we ended up chatting for half an hour and she had me laughing the whole time. On the promenade where they walk, they were posing for a portrait, and they asked if they could kiss. I obviously told them to go for it."

b'Congratulations to new #CanonExplorerOfLight @lnweatherspoon!

"I started my photography career in 2008, and started using Canon products in 2013 after selling my previous gear. Most of my photography friends were using Canon when I'd hire them as my assistant, and they talked about how great of a system it was. So, I decided to take a chance and never looked back. After transitioning into new gear and understanding my role as a photojournalist, I took my photography and storytelling skills more seriously so that I could value the images as moments that were meant to be archived and cherished. These same skills helped me meet some of my idols and share stories that have a place in the historical aspect of not only African American history, but world history.

I'm grateful to have the opportunity to share what has been bestowed on me, now as a Canon Explorer of Light. This honor allows me to continue the same work, and set the path for more Black, women, and LGBTQ+ photojournalists and portrait photographers to know that they have a rightful place in documenting everyday life without constraints."

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @charlesglatzer "This image was taken on a moonless night atop the Blue Ridge Pkwy (Cowee overlook), NC. I used a 'Night Sky' filter to help reduce the artificial ambient light and extract detail in the night sky. 

To ensure I do not have any star streaking in my image with high megapixel cameras, I divide my focal length into 400, instead of the typical 500. 400 / focal length (20mm) = 20 sec. 

Additionally, with the EOS R5 you can depress the magnify button once for 6x, twice for 15x in the viewfinder or on the rear LCD screen for critical focus. I find it is best to manually focus and tape the focus ring to make sure it does not shift while shooting."

b'Photo by photographer @nataliekeyssar "In July of 2019, which now feels like another planet, I traveled to Guyana to photograph a story about the country\xe2\x80\x99s oil industry. I spent a lot of time shooting pipeline construction and portraits of very powerful people, but in between I walked the streets and beaches of Georgetown getting to know its gorgeous colors and stunning architecture and surreal juxtapositions. I happened to be there during a heatwave, and it seemed like it was so hot that you could actually see it in the air. I stopped to photograph this little abandoned boat on the shore as a bright yellow bird flew by the word 'deep' written on its side. The image didn\xe2\x80\x99t make the story because, truthfully, it had nothing to do with the story, but my editor and I both loved this quiet moment anyway. I think sometimes as photographers we get a little too into the 'decisive moment.' Those images are great, but truthfully most of my favorite images are the in-between ones like this."

b'"Erica Armah Bra-Bulu Tandoh, also known as @djswitchghana, is an 11-year-old DJ in Ghana. Erica became the youngest person to win Ghana's annual DJ award when she was only 8 years old. Ghana is known for being the 'Gold Coast' as it is the largest producer of gold in Africa. We decided to incorporate gold into Erica\xe2\x80\x99s shoot as a nod to her Ghanaian heritage. Her look was inspired by both hip-hop and cultural elements to showcase her as a revolutionary young leader. This photo was photographed in studio with one large 7ft octabox light source to the right of the model and one strip box with grid placed to my left for fill. You can learn more about Erica\xe2\x80\x99s story in our upcoming photo book, Glory, which is currently available for pre-order in all major bookstores."

b'Photo by @blair.bunting "When photographing trains, your ears are just as important as your eyes. For this shot I set up in a place where I knew the train was climbing a hill. I listened to the tone of the engines as it neared, and judged the speed of it well before it arrived. With an approximate speed in mind, I set the shutter to maximize sharpness and then used the control ring on the lens to dial in ISO for proper exposure as the train arrived.\xe2\x80\x9d

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @ricksammonphotography "'I want to get a photograph that truly depicts the exotic feeling and mood of an African photo safari.' That\xe2\x80\x99s what I said to my wife Susan when, before going on our fourth photo safari, she asked me, 'What\xe2\x80\x99s the one photograph that you really want to get on this trip?' (Actually, I think was asking, 'Why do you need another photo safari picture!?') 

She asked because I have thousands of safari images, but some, such as my wildlife head shots, could have been taken in zoos in the United States. What\xe2\x80\x99s more, even some of the wide-angle shots look as though they might have been taken in wildlife parks, some of which offers realistic settings. With my goal in mind, I set out to get a shot of an African animal silhouetted against a dramatic golden sunset \xe2\x80\x93 the kind of sunset that you don\xe2\x80\x99t see at a wildlife park. 

On day two of our safari, we encountered a giraffe silhouetted against the setting sun. After directing my driver to find the best location for the shot, the scene illustrated two composition rules: 1) the giraffe, sun and tree illustrated the 'rule of odds,' and 2) each element in the scene was isolated, illustrating the rule of 'separation.' After framing my shot and setting my exposure compensation to -2.33 (in order to keep the edges of the sun crisp so it looked like a ball of light), I shot and accomplished my goal. 

Sure, tech stuff, like exposure composition and knowing the rules of composition, is good to know, but always remember that mood matters most in any photograph. It\xe2\x80\x99s also important, very important, to set goals \xe2\x80\x93 in our photography and of course in our life."

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @michelecelentanophotographer "Natalie reminds me of a wild haired princess. She is strong willed, knows what she wants and won\xe2\x80\x99t let anyone get in her way. That\xe2\x80\x99s my kind of princess. I wanted to create a fierce image that showed strength and character. With Natalie\xe2\x80\x99s gorgeous red hair, milky skin and piecing eyes I knew she could pull off the look I wanted. I used a fan to blow her hair but I used it behind to to make the hair more forward around her face not moving back. The headpiece is a necklaced I pinned in her hair (the fan was moving it with her hair). Simple soft make-up was the way to go with the look I wanted to create. b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @michelecelentanophotographer "Family portraits are what I photograph the most. It\xe2\x80\x99s not often I get to create something a bit more moody and on the fashion side of photography. I found the earrings and thought the colors and texture of them were really interesting. As they say in beauty photography \xe2\x80\x9cthe hero\xe2\x80\x9d of the shot. I wanted everything else in the image to be almost monochromatic and styled everything else around the earrings. I used just enough wind from the fan to move her back a little bit so that the earring would shine through. One light over head to carve out her cheek bones was all I used to light her. Sometime simple with one attention drawing element can set the tone of an image."

b'#CanonExplorerOfLight @michelecelentanophotographer is taking over our Instagram today! "This image is a bit \xe2\x80\x9c70s Pop icon\xe2\x80\x9d inspired. I found the purple wig in NYC last year and then sunglasses at a local store. Sometimes I see something in a store and think \xe2\x80\x9cI have to style a photo session around that.\xe2\x80\x9d The sunglasses did that for this shoot. 

For the lighting here I used a beauty dish but moved it camera left to create a bit more dimension in her face and did not use a reflector so the lighting would drop off a bit more dramatically. I also used a kicker light behind her to add highlights to the hair. One of my favorite things to do lately is hang out in my studio and experiment with different lighting techniques. It\xe2\x80\x99s not something we can usually do when working with clients so it always fun to create a self project."

b'"I haphazardly snapped this photo during one of our fall visits to Zion. I noticed this view as we were driving by, and made my husband quickly pull over so that I could run back and capture it while he waited in the car with our napping infant. (Don't worry, I swapped with him on baby duty so that he could also run back and admire the beauty!) What caught me off guard about this particular moment, on this particular day, was the light. The sky was a mix of clouds and sun, constantly changing how the light hit the landscape. During this fortuitous morning, there was no one out here but me. It felt almost like a "secret" to be witnessing this soft light with these lovely fall colors. Completely unplanned and totally inspiring. It almost looked like a painting instead of real life. b'#BehindTheShot with #CanonExplorerOfLight @dorn.bruce 

"I recently co-hosted a Western Lifestyle photography workshop with my good friend, Chris Dickinson. Our goal is to always create fun-filled sessions that are rich in learning opportunities. This session with Maverick & his gentle Palomino, Pee Wee, was both typical & quite special!
 
We teach that our photographer\xe2\x80\x99s visual voice is defined by 'where we stand' -- both philosophically & physically. In this session we were demonstrating the importance of camera position with exercises in High & Low Angle work. Much of our time is spent on the instruction of 'blind firing' -- a technique that relies on instinctually aiming the camera without looking through the viewfinder. Once mastered, it allows the photographer who uses a camera that does not have a swiveling LCD to easily get interesting shots from bird\xe2\x80\x99s eye & worm\xe2\x80\x99s eye points-of-view -- perspectives that are otherwise difficult or impossible to achieve. Serendipitously whacky compositions are also commonplace with this technique & oftentimes quite lovely! It does take a while to master but it pays off to be persistent.
 
In this more formally-composed long-lens example I had the advantage of the Canon EOS R5\xe2\x80\x99s swiveling LCD touchscreen. I knew that rough-and-tough Maverick was about to unload Pee Wee & I knew my POV needed to be dang close to subterranean in order to tell the story from the cutest perspective. I could have laid on my belly but not wanting to get ants in my pants I twisted the LCD to be parallel with the ground, cradled the zoom in one hand & triggered the shutter by gently tapping on the screen. Timing is everything and I got 2 wonderful moments where everything came together perfectly.
 
I must say, I love the new RF system! The RF 100-500mm F/4.5-7.1L IS USM zoom is a worthy successor, the proven EF 100-400mm F4.5-5.6L IS USM and the Canon R5\xe2\x80\x99s 45MP sensor, IBIS, and exquisite color science were well worth the wait. I processed my RAW files in Canon\xe2\x80\x99s DPP RAW processor & shot for the pastel-tinted feel of vintage color print. I think I hit the bull\xe2\x80\x99s eye with this one!"
 
Camera: Canon EOS R5
Lens: RF100-500mm F4.5-7.1 L IS USM'

b'Life\xe2\x80\x99s a journey \xe2\x80\x94 capture every adventure with the Canon IVY CLIQ+ Instant Camera Printer. Small enough to fit in your pocket or bag, the IVY CLIQ+ is a great accessory for every occasion.'

b'(2/2) "Once we were back at work, though, the adrenaline kept us running. But we didn\xe2\x80\x99t really have time to fully process what was really happening right before our eyes. We\xe2\x80\x99d constantly see our patients crash at the same time and didn\xe2\x80\x99t know where to go\xe2\x80\x94who to help\xe2\x80\x94first. We held young patients\xe2\x80\x99 hands as they died alone, no visitors permitted. We held phones as spouses used them to FaceTime with their young ones to say goodbye.
 
For us, the pain came out once we\xe2\x80\x99d walk out the doors to go home. We leaned on each other a lot during that time, as we still do, becoming even more of a family than we were. We cried in each other\xe2\x80\x99s arms when we lost patients we'd been fighting SO hard to save; we elbow bumped when we actually sent a patient home; and we texted each other nonstop, checking to make sure everyone was OK. I guess you could call it trauma bonding.
 
My co-workers were the ones who encouraged me to take these photos. They know me, and they knew it was hard for me to have all my photoshoots canceled due to the virus. I had no creative outlet, the main coping mechanism helping me combat my depression. Coupled with working a very high stress job, my psyche was being put to the test. So, one of my co-workers suggested I bring my camera to work and take photographs that they we could one day show our grandkids. They could serve as mementos of a time we\xe2\x80\x99d one day be so glad to see in the rearview mirror, but also proud to have helped the world fight through. I came in on my day off and tried to capture everything with my camera, hoping to be able to show people what it\xe2\x80\x99s really like behind those sealed doors."

b'(1/2) "I still remember that day like any other day in the ICU, until it wasn't. A whole group of us received a casual email telling us we\xe2\x80\x99d be part of the team staffing the COVID-19 ICU at our hospital in Chicago. It told us what to do and where to report, but this wasn\xe2\x80\x99t any other email -- this was telling us we\xe2\x80\x99d be working on the front lines of a global pandemic that, at the time, we knew very little about.
 
Walking into the unit that first day was surreal. Typically filled with healthcare workers and visitors, the empty white hallways were like something out of a movie. Doorways were taped off with plastic, the sound of the huge, negative pressure fans whirled and there were signs everywhere warning all not to enter the 8th floor under any circumstances\xe2\x80\x94unless you were us, of course.
 
It\xe2\x80\x99s a very weird feeling, walking into a place that you very well know is dangerous, and even life-threatening, but not fully understanding how that threat operates. We knew we could get the virus at any time, but we didn\xe2\x80\x99t know how we\xe2\x80\x99d react to it. We saw and cared for critically-ill patients and often wondered if we\xe2\x80\x99d be next. Sadly, that ended up being the reality for a couple of my coworkers.
 
Still, we worked a lot in those first couple months, often 80-hour weeks. We all suffered from insomnia, and even when we could manage to fall asleep, nightmares of the hospital bled through."'

b'"Glory is a photography book that shatters the conventional standards of beauty for black children. In the book, @creativesoulphoto highlights a wide variety of kids across the African diaspora. @amoy.antunet is a 9-year-old neuroscientist from Atlanta, Georgia. Her love for science began at the age of three, when she became fascinated with a microscope belonging to her father. She has been featured in several media outlets around the world and is currently the youngest person ever to present at a neural convention. For our shoot with Amoy, we decided to incorporate our love of sci-fi for this shot to create an Afrofuturism look. Her futuristic arm piece was created from toys spray painted to match the scene. For her robotic neck, we took a photo of a toy robot in the same lighting and merged it with her photo in Photoshop." 

Photo Credit: @creativesoulphoto

b'"This next week marks the first days of school for children all over the US and the world. What a moment in history to document. School should certainly not look like this. My hope is that we will look back one day at these memories with an increased sense of gratitude. We most certainly can\xe2\x80\x99t lose hope...our children are watching."

b'"One day this summer, I was driving down a long stretch of empty Idaho highway just as golden hour began to paint the mountains with warm, bright light. One minute the skies were bright blue and clear but in an instant a dark storm moved in. Flash forward to me running with my tripod up and down the highway in a frenzy of awe and disbelief! One bald eagle, two rainbows, and a thousand golden raindrops later, I found myself feeling overwhelmed and so incredibly grateful for this amazing world we live in! This summer was all about finding beauty in the small things and shining a light into the darkness." Thank you for sharing your #CanonMemories with us, @macelliottmedia. :rainbow:

Good news - there isn't. This means long-time Canon shooters can confidently go out and shoot on the EOS R5 with their trusted EF lenses. I shot this one with my workhorse, the 16-35 f/2.8 III along with a neutral density filter to smooth out the turquoise water."

b'"The connection I share with my mustang Liberty has inspired me to travel to remote, rugged locations in pursuit of photographing wild horses. One of my dreams was to visit where Liberty was born and roamed free for the first 3 years of her life in Cold Springs, Oregon.  It is very difficult to access and find the wild mustangs that live there, but my biggest challenge was not spooking them so I could take photos. I spent several days looking for the herd and found a watering hole that they visited once a day. I spent hours hiding in sagebrush, waiting for the right light and the right moment. The last day of my trip, after waiting 8 hours for the horses to come to the waterhole I had what I can only call magic; not only did the horses come close enough to capture some beautiful portraits, but the light was beautiful and soft.  The memories of that trip to photograph where my Liberty is from are ones that I will carry with me forever." :red_heart_selector::horse_face:Thank you for sharing your #CanonMemories with us, @4005wildhorseimages / @jessicafarrenphotography.
:camera:Camera: #Canon EOS 5DS R
Lens: EF70-200mm f/2.8L IS II USM

b'"One of the greatest things I share with my grandpa is a passion for photography. I used to drive down and visit him so we could go into the great outdoors and capture what we saw. Unfortunately, we can't really do that nowadays. I was sad when I first realized that I wouldn't be able to go down at all this summer, but my Navy Vet, ex heart surgeon grandpa wasn't having any of that hubbub. He challenged me to go out on my own and take photos as if we were together and he would do the same. We would take photos together, but apart. That led me to take my favorite photo I have created yet. A picture of Paulina Lake in Eastern Oregon. A photo with my grandpa without my grandpa. It is one of the ways my Canon camera has given me more than just a tool to take a photo." :blue_heart:
Thank you for sharing your #CanonMemories with us, @graemewiltrout.

b'Find out what's in #CanonExplorerOfLight @jeremycowart's gear bag! \xe2\x80\x9cI can\xe2\x80\x99t fit ALL of this into my camera bag, but this is a look at what rotates in and out of it regularly. I\xe2\x80\x99m now obsessed with the new Canon EOS R5 and it\xe2\x80\x99s become my flagship camera. Previously, I was relying on the Canon EOS 5DS for my studio portraits.

My go-to lens right now for the EOS R5 is the RF 50mm F1.2 L USM lens. When I\xe2\x80\x99m shooting in studio, I throw on the adapter and shoot with the EF 24-70mm 2.8 USM or the EF 85mm f/1.2L USM and sometimes the EF 70-200mm f/2.8L II USM lens. I love shooting with the EF 100-400mm F4.5-5.6L IS II USM lens when I\xe2\x80\x99m documenting my kid\xe2\x80\x99s sports or at the beach. (Yes, I\xe2\x80\x99m brave enough to take gear out to the beach ha.)

Other must haves\xe2\x80\xa6 a mask (thanks Covid), my Profoto B10 Plus (incredible tool), Profoto air remote to trigger the B10 Plus, CF and SD cards, water, hard drives from G-Technology, my tether cable from Tether Tools, my cable pouch from Peak Design, lens cleaning cloths, glasses, pen, keys, and of course my iPad Pro and Apple Pencil. I love digitally drawing over my photos. I also take traditional colored pencils and a sketchbook. I threw in my own book cause I needed to fill the space haha.

Is anyone spotting my first-ever Canon digital camera\xe2\x80\xa6 the Canon G1?!?! How fun is that? I think they released it in 2001! 

Lastly, I just created my brand new 2020 gear guide for the full rundown of what I\xe2\x80\x99m using in the studio these days. If you want to access it, just join my email list at jeremycowart.com and you\xe2\x80\x99ll get immediate access."'

b'Photo by #CanonLegend @denisreggie "Rather than focus on the wide view of this picturesque waterfall in Iceland, I used my EF 70-200mm f/2.8L lens to concentrate on the shadowy area below where water crashed into a nearly hidden pool surrounded by huge boulders. I used a Canon EOS-1Ds Mark III in Av mode at f/6.3 at 1/250 second at ISO 200. I love the ethereal feel of this cool misty scene in one of the most stunning photography destinations on Earth."'

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @roberto_photo with the new EOS R5 "This was a fun look to photograph. The fashion here was bigger than life, and impossible not to notice. It truly is something special. Therefore, I wanted to go outside and photograph next to the biggest Joshua Tree I could find, that also appeared bigger than life. I chose to photograph them from a lower angle with the RF 15-35mm F2.8 L IS USM lens at 24mm to exaggerate the model\xe2\x80\x99s size and perspective. For the light, we had to use a large Profoto Octabox in order to provide realistic lighting on both models without the risk of creating unwanted shadows. I thoroughly enjoy interesting fashion, and thus, this was one of my favorite looks of the day."

b'#BehindTheShot with #CanonExplorerOfLight @zaknoyle "Shooting with such a long lens I knew I had to view things differently, I needed to challenge myself to look at every day scenes and make them work. This is shot from Magic Island at Ala Moana Beach park, a location frequented by many. The shot you see here, is of a surf break many breaks down the way. Utilizing the long lens, I have the wall in the foreground with a wave breaking splashing up. Thanks to the amazing tracking focus on the new EOS R6, I was able to keep my subject in focus with everything happening in the foreground and background. This is while hand holding the 800mm lens and 2x extender and shooting over half a mile away of high action into the glaring sunlight."

b"\xe2\x80\x9cI am a wildlife photographer and spend most of my time photographing whales and dolphins. This was my first trip on the water with the new R5 camera and RF600mm lens, and I found some very challenging subjects, including short-beaked common dolphins that were launching themselves 20-30 feet from the water. This photo captured one of my all-time favorite experiences I\xe2\x80\x99ve had with the short-beaked common dolphin after being on the water almost biweekly for the past three years.\xe2\x80\x9d :dolphin: Thank you, @ace_visuals, for being a part of #TeamCanon and sharing your #CanonMemories with us.

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @dorn.bruce "Sunset Ride. I was location scouting in southwestern Utah with Country Western recording artist, Chris Peterson (and his dun mare, Sisco!) when we were blessed with this stunning sunset. I\xe2\x80\x99ll be shooting Chris\xe2\x80\x99 next music video with my new Canon EOS R5 so it made sense to use the very same camera for a series of location stills. 

With Chris and Sisco soaked in local color, I quickly twisted on my Canon RF 70-200mm F/2.8L IS zoom lens, punched in to 200mm, selected ISO 200, chose a shutter speed of 1/800th, and opened the aperture to F/2.8. The EOS R5\xe2\x80\x99s amazing autofocus and Canon\xe2\x80\x99s legendary color science guaranteed that every shot in the sequence was a keeper. Easy-peasy! :red_heart_selector:

Over the coming weeks I\xe2\x80\x99ll be posting 'behind-the-scenes' updates and 'making of' social media clips as we gallop towards making Chris\xe2\x80\x99 next music video. Lots to see, lots to learn so be sure to ride along on our Western adventure.

See more location scouting pix on my Instagram feed (@dorn.bruce) and follow Chris (@diehardcowboy_) to learn more of his story. He is a talented photographer too!"

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @darrellgulin "Dew drops and flower reflections, which were taken with my new Canon EOS R5 camera in my kitchen studio. In order to get this greater magnification I used 2 Canon extension tubes EF 25 and Canon Extender EF 1.4x III. To get the best balance of light I used the built in HDR program in my EOS R5 camera. I cut some flowers including yellow zinna flowers for subject. The stem is from a dahlia as they have some wax on their stems and hold dew drops. Using a plamp (clamp with extension arm) I held a portion of the dahlia stem horizontal and right behind I placed a vase of flowers. Then I used my very fine mister bottle, to spray on just the right amount of dew drops. Using the natural light coming in from the right and behind along with a soft box light on the left/back to light this image."

Camera: #Canon EOS R5
Lens: EF 180mm f/3.5L Macro USM
Aperture: f/32
ISO: 2000
Shutter Speed: 0.3 sec
Focal Length: 180mm'

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @darrellgulin "Butterfly Polyura phyrrus phyrrus from the Island of Seram, Indonesia. The smaller male is on the left and larger female is on the right side. Genus of this butterfly is Charaxes and called the Tailed Emperor or Four Tailed butterfly. Again almost all of my butterfly images are taken in my kitchen, where I can control the lighting and backgrounds. The lighting used in this case was natural light coming from the right and back of the butterfly.  Also I used one soft box light on the left side of the butterfly and finally I used my Canon Macro Twin Lite MT-24EX flash in the fill flash mode at a setting of -1."

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @jeremycowart "Are you the type of photographer that sees the image before you take it? Or do you just set up a shoot and see what happens? Personally speaking, I feel like I'm more of a technician artist. I just set up all the gear and the lights and the color and I just let it fly. I remember reading an interview with Annie Leibowitz and she talked about how she doesn't really direct her subjects. She just waits and watches and that's kind of how I work too. I'll direct a little bit but I like for the models to do whatever they want. That's what true collaboration is. In this photo though, I did have her purposefully stand halfway under the projector so that the projector only lit half of her face and then my @profotousa strobe lit the rest of her face.

Where does this image take you?"

Model: @thisissophia
Hair, makeup and wardrobe by @fairlight

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @jeremycowart "I am the first to admit in saying that it's really easy to over light things. But then sometimes I realize that one single light is all you need. Sometimes it's a strobe, sometimes it's a flash, and sometimes it's just natural light. But nonetheless sometimes one light source is the most powerful solution possible. This is one of those examples. I had a @profotousa beauty dish positioned right above her aiming straight down. I also lit this shot other ways but none of them compared to the power and simplicity of this photo. Have you ever tried to over light a photo, only to realize that natural light or one light is the best solution? It happens to the best of us.

For more on my process check out my brand new education project @LiminalSociety."

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @jeremycowart "Over the last few years, I have really been exploring projection. I've always wondered how photographers get different types of really tight light. And in many cases I couldn't figure it out. Then I had the idea to start exploring projection. There are all kinds of ways to do it but I have found that it's best to go as bright as you can. You want as many lumens as possible. So I finally started working with Canon projectors and they are insane. I'm currently using the REALiS WX450ST projector in my studio to do all of my projection. I often use two of them, one on the background and one on the subject directly. I love all the crazy results I can get out of it. I'll either find, download, or create custom patterns and shapes in Photoshop. I made this pattern in Photoshop and thought I would give it a shot and I'm very pleased with the results.

Have you ever shot with projection? I really do think it's the most underrated lighting tool in photography.

If you\xe2\x80\x99re interested, I\xe2\x80\x99m now teaching all of my various projection techniques in my brand new project, @LiminalSociety. When members signup, they can give a free 6-month membership to another photographer friend in need! Pretty excited about this and I hope that it helps people in times of need. I\xe2\x80\x99d love to see you all there."

Model: @liza.miggo

b'#CanonExplorerOfLight @jeremycowart taking over the feed today! 

"A trick that I love to use is the @lensbabyusa OMNI creative filter system. I love it because you can get all of these ethereal effects but in camera. I\xe2\x80\x99m not a big fan of adding anything in post, I prefer to get everything in camera. This was shot against the same white wall that I photography everybody in front of. But because I'm changing my projected backdrops and rotating my lights, I can never get the same image twice in a row. The convenience of digital is amazing but I am a perfectionist, so I want every single frame to look completely different and that's possible through my process. Another benefit of having my strobes rotate is that the prisms also change. When a different light fires every frame that forces the prisms to look different in every frame. It's fascinating to see the results. If you want to see the set up and the full process, be sure to check out @liminalsociety where I show all of it.

How does this image make you feel? What does it make you think of?"

Model @julieannaseckler

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @vanessajoy "I have never been so happy to shoot a wedding in all my life. The last wedding I photographed was eight months ago!! There\xe2\x80\x99s nothing quite like watching your weddings, and income, slip away one by one due to a pandemic. To say I\xe2\x80\x99ve had to pivot would be an understatement. 

Carly and Mark\xe2\x80\x99s wedding went through one rescheduling date and then downsized from a 200+ person wedding to the 45 person micro wedding that they had last weekend. It was held in her parents\xe2\x80\x99 backyard right on the Finger Lakes in Skaneateles, NY and it was absolutely beautiful. 

Shooting alongside my husband, wedding videographer at @RobAdamsFilms, made the first wedding back all the better. This photograph was taken against a window in her parents\xe2\x80\x99 home with the new EOS R5 and RF 28-70mm f/2 - a camera and lens combo I\xe2\x80\x99ve simply become addicted to!

For all of the event photographers like me who are desperately itching to get back to work, there\xe2\x80\x99s hope and you are not alone. We\xe2\x80\x99re all in this together and we will see the other side."

b'Find out what's in #CanonExplorerOfLight @lindsayadler_photo's gear bag! "As a fashion photographer in NYC, it is my job to capture beauty, emotion, detail and elegance. The concept and purpose of an image is always the most important consideration, and then I can select the gear that allows me to best capture that underlying concept.

While at times I can certainly fall into the category of \xe2\x80\x98gear nerd\xe2\x80\x99 and feel like I need everything, in truth I find myself using the same key pieces of equipment over and over again. 

Now that I\xe2\x80\x99ve gotten my hands on the Canon EOS R5 I am in love and it is the camera body I grab for everything! For full length shots I almost exclusively choose the RF 24-105. When I get closer to the subject for a beauty image, I\xe2\x80\x99m usually reaching for the 70-200 or the 85 (depending on whether I need versatility or wide apertures). Finally, for my super tight macro beauty work I most often use the 180mm macro to give me a bit more working distance. 

This combination of gear accounts for 8 out of 10 shoots, whether I am on location or in a studio setting."

Gear List: 
Canon EOS R5
Canon RF 24-105mm 4.0 
Canon RF 85mm 1.2 
Canon EF 70-200mm 2.8
Canon EF 180mm 3.5 
Lens Mount Adapter (EF to RF) 

Accessories, Other: 
Lexar 128gb SD cards
Lexar 128gb CF Express cards
X-Rite Passport ColorChecker 
Extra Batteries'

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @stephsinclairpix "An image of the port of Beirut during better times. For four years in the mid-2000's I lived in the amazing cosmopolitan city of Beirut. The Lebanese people remain some of the most talented entrepreneurs on the planet. Their resilience is legendary, as they have always shown an incredible spirit and optimism in starting over in the wake of adversity. One of the reasons humankind has taken to photography so readily and so completely over the past hundred some years is that, whether we understand -- consciously or not -- that moments are fleeting, that meaning ebbs and flows. Nothing in this world is permanent, not even our memories. By capturing someone / something in a photograph or a video, we mere mortals can briefly stop time in its tracks."

b'Find out what's in #CanonExplorerOfLight @davidbergman's gear bag! "The camera has been my all-access pass to historical moments, championship sporting events and concert stages around the world for nearly 30 years. Most recently, I was on the road with Bon Jovi and Luke Combs while also hosting my exclusive #shootfromthepit live concert photography workshops. As a tour photographer, my goal is to capture the show in a new way each night while also documenting life on the road for the artists and their fans.

Running thousands of frames though my cameras every day means that the gear I use has to withstand the enormous pressures I put on it. The Canon EOS-1D X Mark II - and now the Mark III - bodies are built to last, shoot 14-20 frames a second, and handle high ISOs like 6400 and 12,800 without a problem. I carry two on my shoulders during the show with the EF 24-105 and 100-400 lenses so I can quickly switch from wide to tight without missing any of the action on stage.

I use remote cameras to make unique images from locations that may not be accessible during the show. I put another EOS-1D X Mark II on stage with a 24-70 2.8, and the smaller/lighter EOS 5D Mark IV overhead in the lighting truss with the 11-24. My fifth traveling body is the full-frame EOS R mirrorless with the RF 28-70 f/2, which is like having three prime lenses in one. Because I can shoot silently and in very low light, I carry this setup with me backstage during the day to capture candid moments using only available light. I have the EF-EOS-R adapter just in case I want to use the R with one of my EF lenses.

I always have at least one 600EX II-RT Speedlite to shoot the artist\xe2\x80\x99s 'meet and greet' photos, and can make a simple one light portrait using the ST-E3-RT wireless transmitter if the opportunity arises. The other items needed to complete my kit include remote mounting hardware and transceivers, a card wallet, backup hard drives, in-ear monitors, and gaffers tape."'

b'#BehindTheShot with #CanonExplorerOfLight @Vanessajoy "This is not a shot I expected to take, but since I was in a gorgeous NYC skyrise I couldn't settle for taking natural light photos that blew out the skyline. But the key part for me in making this photo work, wasn't just the lighting, it was the lens choice. Normally I'm a sucker for a 50mm 1.2 lens, but I've been happily using the RF 28-70mm f/2 L USM lately because of the nice low aperture that I love and the ability to zoom in and out at will rather than changing a lens. That really came in handy here since the model had a beautifully flowy dress on and I wanted to enhance its movement and size. I was able to zoom all the way out at 28mm and duck a little bit lower, just enough to let the lens distortion work for me and accentuate the dress. Shooting at 1/200th of a second was the perfect speed to let a little motion blur happen in the dress, but still keep my model's face tack sharp - plus with the Canon EOS R5's incredible auto focus technology I had no problem locking onto her eye for perfect focus even with the dress moving around in front of her face.

Swipe left for a look at the EOS R5's 4k 120p video (because who wouldn't want to play with that if you can?!) a behind the scenes video of this shoot for @Adorama with @alliecizek."

ISO: 200
Shutter Speed: 1/200 sec
Focal Length: 28mm'
