b'#BehindTheShot with #CanonExplorerOfLight @georgelepp "A small African violet houseplant may seem simple, but it actually has a complex structure that is not easily conveyed in a photograph, because at high magnifications depth of field is quite limited. One of my favorite techniques for such subjects is focus bracketing (also called focus stacking), where a series of images are captured at slightly overlapping planes of focus, then composited in post-capture software into one sharply detailed image file. While I have accomplished this process manually for many years, Canon\xe2\x80\x99s EOS RP, 90D, and the new EOS R5 have automated the focus-bracketing capture process in camera. For this image, I brought the plant into the studio with the tripod-mounted EOS R5 and the Canon EF 100mm f/2.8L Macro IS USM lens and set the camera to capture 71 focus-bracketed images at f/8, ISO 400. I lit the setup with three small, inexpensive LED lights: two positioned to the right and left of the subject, with the left about 1.5 stops less intense, and one diffused light attached to the lens, just bright enough to fill in the dark areas at the base of the plant. When the captures were composited in Zerene Stacker software, all the rich textures that comprise this beautiful plant were revealed!"

Focal Length: 100mm'

b'Photo captured on the new EOS R6 by #CanonExplorerOfLight @roberto_photo "This photo is one of the reasons why I love the EOS R6\xe2\x80\x99s incredible Auto Focus technology paired with the flip screen. To take this photograph, I had to stand on a large boulder with pretty strong wind blowing on my body rocking me left and right. I used the new RF 15-35mm lens in order to make it look like I was much higher than I was. Even though I was moving quite a bit, and I had to hold the camera with my right arm extended all the way out, I was so excited to see that the camera\xe2\x80\x99s Dual Pixel Auto Focus II system didn\xe2\x80\x99t have any problems tracking their eyes no matter how much I swayed. The flip screen was incredibly useful to pop it out and angle it towards me to ensure everything was going well with the AF, and to create my composition."

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @georgelepp "Every wildlife photographer dreams of trekking around with a hand-held camera and super telephoto lens combo able to reach out and capture elusive subjects. Oh, wait! Did I mention we want the camera to be fast (how about 12, even 20 frames per second?), have a great sensor with lots of resolution (make that 45 MP), and let\'s ask for clean high ISOs (800 to 6400+ for a start). The lens needs to be really light and preferably small (I could hand-hold an 800mm lens that\'s 2.77 lbs. and 13.85 inches long). Guess what? That dream system now exists and you are looking at an image that proves it. These duckweed-feeding trumpeter swans with three 4-week-old cygnets were photographed with the new Canon EOS R5 and the RF800mm F11 IS STM lens at 1/2000 sec., f/11, and ISO 800. Hand-held!"'

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @49ersofficialphotog "I was so excited when my package arrived from Canon USA, I was like a kid on Christmas ready to get my hands on the new EOS R5 mirrorless camera to try out. Also, in the box was the new RF 100-500mm f/4.5-7.1L IS lens, I could not wait to see what I could produce with these products. 
 
But as you know there were no sports happening around the country, so I had to figure out what I could capture in a short amount of time that would look and feel genuine. So, one of my photography assistants got a few high school soccer players to come out in the uniforms and run drills on the soccer field. This gave me a chance to really test out the EOS R5 and RF 100-500mm f/4.5-7.1L IS lens as if I was shooting from the sidelines. 
 
I was also amazed from the start on how well the EOS R5 performed out the box for the first time I was photographing with it, and the RF 100-500mm f/4.5-7.1L IS lens was fantastic. The image quality was excellent, and the auto tracking was on point. So, I was able to produce some great images on day one after receiving these new products. I really believe the new EOS R5 and EOS R6 will be a game changer in the industry."

b'Astrophotographer @babaktafreshi went out and shot new exciting footage with the EOS Ra camera. "A celestial visitor setting at dusk over a lake in New Hampshire. Comet NEOWISE, the brightest comet in years, is still remarkable in the long-exposure photos under dark skies, although visually it's fainter to naked eyes. On this July 12th evening I used the Canon EOS Ra with the RF 50mm F1.2 L USM for a timelapse sequence of 300 shots, each 6-second exposure at ISO 3200. 
 
The comet is visible in most of the northern hemisphere, 1-2 hours after sunset over Northwest. If you are above latitude 50 degrees, the later after sunset, the better as it takes much longer for the sky to get dark. Near 55-60 degrees in Canada & Europe for example, try near midnight over northern horizon for darkest hours. In low latitudes near the tropics, the sky becomes darker quicker after sunset, so even an hour after the sunset is enough. The comet begins its display in the Southern Hemisphere from July 23/24th."
#cometneowise #comet #stargazing #canon #eosra'

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @jenwuphoto "In the dim early morning hours, I arrived at the beach next to J\xc3\xb6kuls\xc3\xa1rl\xc3\xb3n in Iceland. It was covered with scattered icebergs! The icebergs were beautiful, like crystals with a sea blue color. The sun shined through the iceberg, making it glow. I used a wide-angle 24mm lens to include the large iceberg and the ocean scene. I waited for waves to reach the iceberg then pressed the shutter to get the wave in action hitting it."

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @jenwuphoto "On a stormy evening with rain and wind at J\xc3\xb6kuls\xc3\xa1rl\xc3\xb3n in Iceland, I found an iceberg covered beach. The blue icebergs and feathery waves beautifully contrasted with the volcanic black sand beach and dark sky. I waited for a wave to crash on the icebergs and took several shots to be sure to capture it. I set the shutter speed to 1 second to photograph the white wispy waves as they receded back to the surf. I used a polarizer to reduce reflections on the sand and iceberg."

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @jenwuphoto "Photographing the Brei\xc3\xb0amerkurj\xc3\xb6kull glacier in Iceland, I went inside an ice cave to take this image. Deep inside the cave with very little light, one wall had a section of smooth blue ice with abstract shapes, reminding me of ocean waves. I decided to create an abstract image by using 70 mm focal length to only including the ice shapes on the the wall and not showing the ice cave ceiling or floor. I used a polarizer and rotated while watching the glare and reflections from the water on the shiny ice diminish, then took the shot."

Camera: #Canon EOS 5D Mark II

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @jenwuphoto "Walking into the ice cave, I turned around to see this view of the blue icebergs as I looked outside. The walls were melting and it felt like a light rain as drops of water fell on me. I used a polarizer to reduce some of the reflections, however you can still see some of the shimmery surface of the melting ice on the boulders and walls. I wanted to photograph a wide view of the cave so I selected the 14 mm wide-angle lens and chose f/11 for plenty of depth of field."

b'Come learn with Canon USA\xe2\x80\x99s Senior Marketing Specialist, Mason Higa, as he shares a few tips and tricks to start your very own vlog. Discover why he chooses to use the EOS M50 Video Creator Kit and a few other tools in this Intro to #Vlogging.'

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @jeremycowart "This portrait was a bit of a revelation for me. It was like years of ideas coming together in one frame. I\xe2\x80\x99ve been pushing the limits of projection for years. Thanks to the extremely bright Canon REALiS WUX450ST Pro AV projector, I was really able to make art using a blank white wall as my backdrop. I typically project my own photos and art, but this particular backdrop is the artwork of my friend @sarah.hart.landolt and her beautiful alcohol ink paintings. So many photographers think projectors are just presentation tools but for me, they\xe2\x80\x99re lighting tools. I use projection in every single photoshoot these days. It\xe2\x80\x99s simply miraculous what can be accomplished. In addition to the projector, I lit her with two Profoto B1 heads with tall strip bank diffusers (with grids) on each side behind her. Then I attached the OmniFilter prisms to my Canon 24-70mm 2.8 lens to create some additional flare. Everything was achieved in camera in terms of effects. I edited the color in Capture One Pro and retouched the skin in Adobe Photoshop. Have you ever used projectors for your photos before?"

b'#BehindTheShot with #CanonExplorerOfLight @davidbergman "As photographers, we can control where the viewer\xe2\x80\x99s eye goes so that our images have maximum impact. I recently set up a photo shoot to capture volleyball player @jackieannnnn in mid-air and it was important to get rid of any distracting elements in the background. Our eyes go to the brightest part of an image first, so I used a powerful studio strobe with high speed sync capability to increase my shutter speed to 1/4000 second. That froze the motion and also darkened the background - a win-win! The Canon EF 100-400 f/4.5-5.6 lens gave me flexibility to zoom in or out, and the tighter I shot, the more the trees in the background went out of focus. Jackie\xe2\x80\x99s expression is tack sharp in every frame thanks to face and head detection autofocus on the EOS-1D X Mark III body. Lastly, I put the camera all the way on the ground and left some dead space under her because the low angle makes her dive look even more epic. All of these elements together allowed me to create an image that puts you right in the middle of the action without any distractions."

Camera: #Canon EOS-1D X Mark III

Aperture: f/5.6
ISO: 800
Shutter Speed: 1/4000 sec
Focal Length: 182mm'

Then last week Phase 4 opened and Chicago was allowed 50 people at an event. So Jenna and Jeremy and their family decided that there would be no mini wedding, there would be no 2021 wedding, they decided to move forward with their original wedding date and make the most beautiful memories.
 
I was looking for the gritty urban texture to juxtapose the elegant, classic look of Jenna + Jeremy, the white of the crumbling facade complimented the white of her wedding dress. 

The EOS R is perfect, the outstanding focus in low contrast situations and the face/eye detection is spot on giving me confidence to shoot quickly and not turn their wedding day into a photo shoot."

b'Photo by wildlife photography expert and #CanonExplorerOfLight @ricksammonphotography using the new RF 100-500mm f4.5-7.1 L IS USM Lens \xe2\x80\x9cIn wildlife photography, if the eye is not in focus and well lit, you have (and I have) missed the shot \xe2\x80\x93 unless we are going for a silhouette. So the tip is to place the focus point right on the eye when photographing in the one-shot mode. Another tip is to expose for the highlights (the brightest part of the scene). I do that by checking my highlight alert and histogram.\xe2\x80\x9d

b'Photo by wildlife photography expert and #CanonExplorerOfLight @ricksammonphotography using the new RF 800mm f11 IS STM \xe2\x80\x9cWildlife does not always pose or display in bright light. On overcast days and when photographing in the shade, don\xe2\x80\x99t be shy about boosting the ISO. This shot was taken at ISO 16000 (sixteen thousand). Thanks to the way the Canon EOS R6 handles noise, and the sharpness of the Canon RF800mm F11 IS STM lens, it\xe2\x80\x99s still a sharp shot. Of course, technical advice is good, but here\xe2\x80\x99s a non-tech and very important tip: respecting wildlife should be first and foremost in the mind of a wildlife photographer. In other words, you do not want to stress the animal. Ever. That\xe2\x80\x99s where a long lens, like a 800mm, comes in.\xe2\x80\x9d

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @davidbergman \xe2\x80\x9cDid you know it\xe2\x80\x99s possible to make daytime look like night with only one or two Speedlites? I made this image of @anddamm at noon on a sunny day, but used high-speed sync and a couple other tricks to make it look much later. With my Speedlite 600EX RT in a small softbox just out of frame on the right side, HSS allowed me to raise the shutter speed on my EOS R to 1/8000 second, which darkens the background considerably. I also set my camera\xe2\x80\x99s white balance to tungsten, making everything more blue and simulating the cool color hue at twilight. I added a full CTO warming gel on my Speedlite, which compensates for the blue color on Andreas, so the light that\xe2\x80\x99s hitting him appears to be neutral. To complete the effect, I added a bare Speedlite on the left to create separation on the other side of his face, and the flare feels like it might be from the moon or a streetlight."

Camera: #Canon EOS R
Lens: EF 85mm f/1.4L IS USM with Control Ring Mount Adapter EF-EOS R

Aperture: f/4
ISO: 100

b'#BehindTheShot with #CanonExplorerOfLight @adam_jones_photo "This American alligator image was a shot I envisioned and tried to capture during many photo safaris in Florida. The situation just never really materialized as envisioned, until last winter with my workshop group at Myakka River State Park, near Sarasota. This image was captured at 1200mm, from a safe distance from this primitive reptile. Lying flat on my belly, my tripod was positioned at ground level right at the edge of the water for a dramatic low angle view. Alligators are quite common in Florida, but it\xe2\x80\x99s not every day they line up head on looking right down the lens barrel. Then a red dragonfly landed on his head, to literally cap off this fun shot. It took a couple attempts to get the alignment perfect, the alligator was watching a fisherman standing close to my camera position. I know this specimen was over 10ft, because we got a great look at him as he lunged out of the water and charged the fisherman and gulped down his fish. 

The super telephoto lens permitted a frame filling shot from a safe distance with no cropping. I encourage students to learn to use teleconverters and stop worrying about loss of quality. With good technique, the 600 III and 2x III combination is easily professionally sharp."

Camera: #Canon EOS-1D X Mark III

b'#BehindTheShot with #CanonExplorerOfLight @joelgrimesworkshops "This image of Leah was created using three Canon 600 EX-RT Speedlites; two were illuminating the white background, one was in a 24 inch Beauty Dish placed over the camera pointing to the subject. I created two exposures. For the first, all three Speedlites were triggered, but on the second exposure, just the two background lights would go off. This gives me one image that is completely silhouetted. Then in Photoshop, using a mask I can selectively reveal or paint in the first exposure image as needed. In this case, I just painted in the face. For the camera, I used the Canon EOS 5DS R with the Canon EF 24-70mm f/2.8L USM lens. F/7.1 200th ISO 100"'

b'|No Limits|
\xe2\x80\x9cAs a visual artist, I started out taking self-portraits with my 7D back in 2014. In order to capture this image, I had to set the self-timer, run out in front of the camera, and jump as high as I could with a bouquet of balloons in my hand. It was quite a comical sight to see, but this artwork really represents me rising above all my fears and insecurities. Canon equipment has truly helped me express myself as I overcame depression, found my voice, and achieved success as an artist. What I love most about Canon equipment is the ease of use and I\xe2\x80\x99m an avid fan of their prime lenses." ...

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @erinbabnik "Landscape photography often requires fast action when conditions are changing rapidly. On this evening I was leading my workshop group in a vast, remote area of the Icelandic Highlands as a storm started to clear. We had been photographing in another area where the moody light of the storm worked well with features on the ground, but as the storm suddenly began to lift, I made the call to get back into our super trucks so that we could drive to the edge of the cloud shelf. We found it when we reached this ridge of peaks, where I could see a series of volcanos and hints of a cliff that suggested a valley below. With only minutes to spare before the sun would set, I leaped out of the vehicle and called for the group to follow me. We grabbed our gear, and I ran full-speed to the edge of the cliff, veering further to the left as I saw the snaking river leading in that direction. In moments like this one, it helps to have many years of experience to draw upon in making instinctive decisions. Navigating only on a hunch, I was delighted when I found that the snaking river aligned beautifully with the illuminated volcano in the distance. We did not have long to enjoy this scene before the sun dipped below the horizon, but that short time was all that we needed to create photographs that we will enjoy forever."

b'#BehindTheShot with #CanonExplorerOfLight @peterreadmiller "This was an adult flag football team that I shot for a workshop this Spring in South Carolina.

I was fortunate to try out the Canon EOS-1D X Mark III camera to shoot the end of the pro playoffs. The camera\xe2\x80\x99s performance blew me away. The AF was the best I have ever seen in a DSLR and the files were beautiful. The EF 200-400 f4 IS USM lens I was using for this shoot was perfect for this situation. I was able to frame each play whether it was a short pass over the middle or a long one.

During the games I always shoot looking through the viewfinder, but for this shoot I put the camera in Live View and used a Hooploupe attached to the LCD screen. I set the AF on Wide Zone Horizontal, turned on face and helmet detection and eye detection (which is only available in Live View). The AF performance was stunning. Shooting Live View can be a little cumbersome, unless your camera is on a tripod (which are not allowed at most sporting events), but I still plan to try it this season, whenever that will be."

Lens: EF 200-400 F4 IS USM

Shutter Speed: 1/1600 sec
ISO: 800'

b'Find out what\'s in #CanonExplorerOfLight @bobanddawn_inthewild\'s gear bag! | "Weddings and events are exciting milestone moments in people\'s lives, I love the challenge of capturing these fleeting moments. My goal is to capture the couple in the best possible light, both literally and figuratively. Everything in this kit is here for the sole purpose of telling the story of the day. Most everything I photograph is on location. I never want to be in the creative zone and wish I had a softbox or a macro lens with me! Cameras today are so amazing, providing us creatives the ability to take pictures in almost any conditions, but that doesn\'t always mean the available is the best option for creating photographs of our clients. Speedlites allow me to create the light I see in my imagination, and never be a victim of poor available light. I use Speedlites to add that spark of light, the catchlights in the eyes that bring the photograph to life. I use all the light available to me, my style is a blend of natural light and off-camera flash to make the best possible picture in any situation I find myself in."'

b'Find out what\'s in #CanonExplorerOfLight @erinbabnik\'s gear bag! | "I typically need to hike, in order to reach the types of areas that I most enjoy photographing, so usually I carry only one camera body and a couple of lenses as my primary gear. Lately my favorite choices have been the EOS 5D Mark IV, the 11-24mm f/4L and the 100-400mm f/4.5-5.6L II, but sometimes I mix it up a bit with other lenses. The accessories that I carry don\xe2\x80\x99t vary much, since I always like to have my TC-80N3 remote, at least a couple of spare batteries, lens cleaning supplies, and a few wrenches that fit the screws on my tripod and L-bracket. Polarizing and neutral density filters usually have a place in my bag, along with my lens support bracket, and my Hoodman Loupe. An ample supply of SD and Compact Flash cards rounds out my photography kit, and I always carry two zippered pouches for them so that I can separate empty cards from used ones easily.\n\nAs a certified Wilderness First Responder, I take safety very seriously, and I always carry a first aid kit and CPR mask. Other safety items in my bag typically include an InReach personal locator beacon, a walkie talkie, a headlamp with spare battery, and power brick to keep all of these items charged. These days I\xe2\x80\x99m also careful to pack an f-stop gear Dyota AG+ Ion face mask for when I might be around other people. Lastly, when I\xe2\x80\x99m heading out for a lengthy or strenuous hike, I always pack my trusty trekking poles. Not pictured here are extra layers of clothing, a hat, gloves, sunglasses, a water bladder or bottle, and food supplies, all of which vary a lot depending on the outing."'

b'#BehindTheShot with @lindsayadler_photo | "When you create images inspired by the past, you imbue your photographs with a sense of timelessness. In my work I regularly am inspired by vintage hairstyles, makeup looks, theatrical clothing, paintings, sculpture and more. With these concepts, my goal is to take more classic themes and add a modern twist. For this shoot I wanted to create an image loosely inspired by Renaissance concepts of beauty, but add a modern fashion editorial flair to the imagery. First, I chose hair styling and clothing to channel that aesthetic. Next, I printed a large sky/cloud background so I could capture as much as possible in camera without compositing. Finally, I added the lighting elements. This shoot had 4 different strobes; an overhead umbrella for general illumination, a grid of the face for more brightness and contrast, a light on the background for separation, and a hair light for a bit of heavenly glow. I worked with the Canon 24-105mm lens shooting wide open at F4 to put the background out of focus slightly for more painterly results." Camera: #Canon EOS 5D Mark IV
Lens: EF 24-105mm f/4L IS II USM
Aperture: f/4
ISO: 100
Shutter Speed: 1/200 sec
Focal Length: 105mm'

b'#BehindTheShot with #CanonExplorerOfLight @damianstroh | "I have photographed a lot of sports in my time as a photographer, but when Canon came to me and asked me to lead a workshop on wind surfing I had to give it some thought. I knew absolutely nothing about the sport. Of course, I've adapted to a lot of unusual sports, bullfighting and lawn mower racing come to mind. So I accepted the gig, thinking it would be fun and started making plans. 
It turns out an old colleague from my newspaper days, John Chao, was an expert windsurfer and at one time a professional. I contacted John and he showed me a lot about how the sport worked and what to expect on the water. He was an absolute and unbelievable resource, and to top it off he lived in the town where we were holding the workshop in, Hood River, Oregon. He had all the inside information. .
The day of the workshop dawned with a promise of some pretty stiff wind so the students and I were excited to get into shooting.

Canon rounded up a bunch of guys to sail and I went over some things with the students that I do to prepare for a shoot:
- Camera gear and controls set and ready to photograph.
- Determine your correct lens, shutter speed, aperture, and ISO.
- Watch the athletes a few times and make a mental plan of where you expect the action to happen.
- Check in with the athletes and see what they are thinking going forward so you can determine whether you need to adjust your position, or your camera settings.
- Don't be scared to try something new!

The windsurfers were a great bunch and we had a lot of fun making the photographs. It was a challenge but we made some nice frames. For the students my hope was that they would all leave the day with a photograph they liked and I think we accomplished that goal." Camera: #Canon EOS-1D Mark IV
Lens: EF 400mm f/2.8L IS USM
Aperture: f/4
ISO: 200
Shutter Speed: 1/2000 sec
Focal Length: 400mm'

b'#BehindTheShot with #CanonExplorerOfLight @charlesglatzer | "Be Pro-Active, rather than Re-Active. Having the exposure set in camera before the decisive moment is paramount to producing consistently successful imagery. Last thing you want to do when the stars align is have the image over or under exposed! .
.
Originally, the egret was in full sunlight, an easy exposure, as it is consistently the same for every white bird in full sunlight (1/1250 @ f/8, ISO 200). This is the Sunny f/16 Reference -2/3 stop for white highlights. For cameras with less dynamic range you may need to close down a 1 full stop from Sunny f/16 (f/22), or 1/1600 @ f/8, ISO 200. .
.
When the egret moved into a heavily shaded area I had to use an alternate method to determine the exposure. I typically use Manual mode with a Spot meter pattern. However, with a Digital DSLR the fastest way to verify your exposure prior to depressing the shutter is to use \xe2\x80\x9cLive View with the Histogram showing\xe2\x80\x9d. Make sure Exposure Simulation is turned on. It\xe2\x80\x99s simple...turn on Live View, and adjust variables for proper exposure, shut off Live View, and shoot. With Canon\xe2\x80\x99s Dual Pixel AF you can focus, track, and shoot all while in Live View. You can do this with a Mirrorless camera through the EVF as well. .
.
Techniques such as Exposing to the Right (ETR) and having a firm grasp in postproduction techniques will allow you to extract all the information recorded in capture."
.
.
Camera: #Canon EOS-1D X 
Aperture: f/5.6
ISO: 800
Shutter Speed: 1/1000 sec'

b'\xe2\x80\x9cLast week was special and I don\xe2\x80\x99t think I\xe2\x80\x99ll ever forget it. I opened up my studio for free portraits to the local black community. It took 3 Canon projectors and 3 laptops to pull it off. I photographed everything with the Canon 5Ds and the 24-70mm 2.8 lens.
.
.
.
I projected brutality victims onto the screen in front of my lens, then behind them, I projected their words, writing, thoughts, lyrics, whatever they wanted to project.
.
.
.
The whole studio became a party but a meaningful one. At times, we were near tears or laughing or just sharing in the moment. I lost count at how many times chills ran down my arms. And I love that everyone just hung out before and after their portraits to soak in the moment.
.
.
.
Be sure to swipe to see the video of how all of this was captured in camera. Also watch my new BLM story highlight to see more photos and BTS.
 #BLMProtestPortraits\xe2\x80\x9d
.
.
.

Thank you for sharing your photos and your voice with us @jeremycowart. We\xe2\x80\x99re proud to have you as part of our #TeamCanon family.'

b"\xe2\x80\x9cA friend of mine asked, \xe2\x80\x98how does it feel to be a black man in America?\xe2\x80\x99 I sighed.
.
.
It hurts my heart to know it\xe2\x80\x99s gotten to this point. As a BLACK photographer, I feel it\xe2\x80\x99s my duty to bring awareness with the loudest voice I have; images. I hope documenting and sharing this time in history will inspire future photographers and help bring context to those who don't understand the reason we march. Images like these remind me how beautiful we as people are, coming together to not only stand up for what we believe in but for what is a human right; a non-negotiable problem society must solve.
.
.
A lot of us might ask ourselves how we should start the conversation about the Black Lives Matter movement. The answer is it starts within your community. It starts with your close friends, the ones you send memes to every day. It starts with having uncomfortable conversations with people that think differently from you, no matter their race. As a son of Caribbean parents who've dealt with more obstacles and had fewer resources than we have now. I know my generation are a resilient bunch. It\xe2\x80\x99s up to us to be that CHANGE and to educate the young ones coming after us.
.
.
CHANGE starts from a single thread, let\xe2\x80\x99s be that thread!\xe2\x80\x9d
.
.
Thank you for sharing your photos and your voice with us @dxtrf. We\xe2\x80\x99re proud to have you as part of our\xc2\xa0#CanonCoLab\xc2\xa0family. #TeamCanon"

b'\xe2\x80\x9cAs the first African American Canon Explorer of Light, the photography community is continually asking me, \xe2\x80\x98How, do I feel? What do I think?\xe2\x80\x99 At this crucial moment in our lives, we are watching our society reel and reject the injustice that has plagued Black lives and other minorities for years. So, in this tumultuous storm, can positivity be found? I believe it can.
.
If you follow me, the majority of my work involves shooting action, such as collegiate and professional sports.  But the worldwide pandemic has sent us inside, and forced us to be quiet. In the quiet, the storm of seeking social justice has now erupted around us, loud enough for not just minorities to hear, but everyone. .
.
George Floyd\xe2\x80\x99s life will not be in vain, because out of the storm of rage, the world has awakened from it slumber and been made to realize Black Lives Matter and going back to \xe2\x80\x98status quo\xe2\x80\x99 is unacceptable. No longer do just the Black and Brown people care, but everyone cares and it is everyone\xe2\x80\x99s responsibility to bring about a positive change. Get your lenses ready, it\xe2\x80\x99s about to happen. Change will come.\xe2\x80\x9d .
.
Thank you for sharing your photos and your voice with us @49ersofficialphotog. We\xe2\x80\x99re proud to have you as part of our #TeamCanon family.'

b'\xe2\x80\x9cThe Color Red.\xc2\xa0#SelfPortraitSunday \xe2\xa0\x80\nAs I was thinking of what concept/color to shoot last week, I kept navigating towards the color red. Red is a color associated with fire and anger, but also of passion and love. As I reflect on these past weeks, my emotions have definitely been a reflection of that. Although many days I have felt angry, I have also felt loved. I wanted this week\'s portrait to be reflective of that. I may be angry, but I am also choosing to continue to spread love.\n#SelfPortraitSunday is an ongoing portrait series where I take a self portrait every Sunday. This project began at the beginning of quarantine and I\xe2\x80\x99m not sure how long we\xe2\x80\x99ll keep this up, but here\xe2\x80\x99s to week 8 :clinking_glasses:" Thanks for sharing your photos and your voice with us,\xc2\xa0@ohyeahitsidy.\xc2\xa0We\'re proud to have you as part of our #TeamCanon\xc2\xa0community.\xc2\xa0:red_heart_selector:'

b"\xe2\x80\x9cIt is necessary for me, as an image maker and as a black man, to be a guardian of the visual identity of my culture and of those that identify with the same heritage as myself. The world and more specifically the industry needs more authentic voices that represent the narrative of Black people worldwide outside of the toxic, stereotypical and deceitful story that has been repeatedly portrayed. One image can change the paradigm.\xe2\x80\x9d Thanks for sharing your photos and your voice with us,\xc2\xa0@shamayim.\xc2\xa0We're proud to have you as part of our #TeamCanon\xc2\xa0community.\xc2\xa0:red_heart_selector:"

b'\xe2\x80\x9cIn this critical time in our fight for justice, we need UNITY. While going out to march for social injustices, I\xe2\x80\x99ve seen pain, hurt, and frustration through my lens. It\'s time to get to know the people that are not like you. Educate yourself on the lives that are not necessarily like yours. Speak up against injustice! We must support and love each other! #BlackLivesMatter #Friendship" Thanks for sharing your photos and your voice with us, @lalearcreative.\xc2\xa0We\'re proud to have you as part of our #TeamCanon community.\xc2\xa0:red_heart_selector:'

b'#BehindTheShot with #CanonExplorerOfLight @roberto_photo | "This photo is very personal and important to me. This is wrangler Joe. He was gracious enough to let me take his portrait during my lighting workshop in Tucson AZ. Not long after this portrait was taken, Joe had a major accident with a horse and left him incapable of riding again. He has been riding horses his entire life. I chose this room to take this portrait because he made all the saddles you see in the background. However, the room was very dark, even in the middle of the day. In order to illuminate the saddles in the background, we used a strobe with a very large umbrella as the light modifier. To create the feeling that Joe is being illuminated by an open door that leads you outside, we used a strobe with a beauty dish. Why a beauty dish on an older gentleman you probably are asking yourself? Because a beauty dish is a mid-hard light modifier. It is the perfect tool to create texture on his face and appreciate his years of experience. I printed this photo on a Canon imagePROGRAF PRO-4000 and had it framed beautifully with old barn wood. The expression on his face when he saw the printed and framed photo was the best gift to me as well as the reason why I absolutely love being a photographer." Camera: Canon EOS 5DS
Lens: EF 50mm f/1.2L USM
Aperture: f/4
ISO: 400
Shutter Speed: 1/80 sec'

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @roberto_photo | "I absolutely love working in harsh light conditions. Hard light, such as in the middle of the day, can provide you with edgy light if desired, or you can transform it in seconds to the most amazing beauty light, which is what I did in this case. There was someone holding a large diffuser, and that transformed the hard light to a soft light. But the key is to get the diffuser as close to the model's face as possible without getting in your frame. The closer the diffuser to the model, the more beautiful the light will be. Someone was holding the light in the back, to create a much needed separation between the model's hair and the wall behind her. Creating separation must appear natural and thus not flashed. However, that separation between the subject and the background, is what gives your photo something special. Most photographers wouldn't take the time to do it. If you do, you will stand out." Model: @rachelc00k
Camera: #Canon EOS 5D Mark IV
Lens: EF 200mm f/2L IS USM
Aperture: f/2
ISO: 100
Shutter Speed: 1/1600 sec'

b'Find out what's in #CanonExplorerOfLight @stephsinclairpix's gear bag! | "Stella, one of my family\xe2\x80\x99s three dogs, shoots me a worrying look as I lay my core camera equipment out for a photograph. She is unusually perceptive and somehow knows my packing up normally means I\xe2\x80\x99ll soon be leaving home on another trip. I am proud to bring the Canon gear shown here on all of my international assignments. Because of its exceptional low light capabilities and silent shutter, I currently use the EOS R for much of my reportage. However, I still adore the EOS 5DS R and the prime lenses you see here for shoots that require faster movement, such as sports, fashion, and documentary situations. I have also found the generous file sizes from the 5DS R to be extremely helpful when making large prints for exhibitions. Not easily seen here are the B&W UV filters on all the lenses and the Sandisk memory cards. And the blue bag is a medical kit sent to me by National Geographic, since I commonly travel to places where quality medicine is limited. To keep everything secure while traveling, I use this lockable hard shell Pelican case.

My core kit consists of the following: 
Canon EOS R Camera Body 
Canon RF 24-105mm f/4L IS USM Lens
Canon RF 35mm f/1.8 IS Macro STM Lens
Canon Control Ring Mount Adapter EF-EOS R
Canon EOS 5DS R Camera Body
Canon EF 35mm f/1.4L USM Lens
Canon EF 50mm f/1.2L USM Lens
Canon EF 85mm f/1.2L II USM Lens
Canon EF 70-200mm f/4L IS USM II Lens
Speedlite 600 EX II-RT
Extender EF 1.4 X III 
4 Canon LP-E6N Lithium-Ion Battery Packs (two already in the camera bodies)"'

b'#BehindTheShot with #CanonExplorerOfLight @tylerstableford | "One of the most memorable shoots I've had as a photographer and filmmaker was flying with a sortie of five F-16 fighter pilots over the Rocky Mountains as part of an assignment for Denver's 5280 Magazine. Here, I captured Major TenEyck LaTourrette flying our two-seater F-16D in formation over Colorado's iconic Pikes Peak.

The project featured the Air National Guard citizen-airmen of the 120th Fighter Squadron at Buckley Air Force Base. Many of the pilots and crew work civilian jobs in the Denver area while also performing full tours of duty overseas. It was an honor to meet the men and women serving our country. 
I captured this shot while trying to recover my wits in the moments after Major LaTourrette surprised me with 7.5 G forces during a vertical "sandbox" takeoff where we went 11,000 feet straight up. The only training I had for heavy G forces prior to the flight was riding swing sets at the park with our kids. On a big swing, I could reach 2 or 3 Gs...but not enough to really prepare for an F-16!" Camera: #Canon EOS-1D Mark IV
Lens: EF 16-35mm f/2.8L II USM
Aperture: f/5.6
ISO: 200
Shutter Speed: 1/640 sec
Focal Length: 23mm'

b'#BehindTheShot with #CanonExplorerOfLight @onnevanderwal | "Shooting from up the mast! I had been on Shaman, a 88ft sailboat in Svalbard archipelago part of the Norwegian Arctic for about two weeks and had had this shot in mind for days, I was waiting for the right time! Finally we had lots of ice, no wind or swell and beautiful arctic light and I thought now or never. I told the owner my idea and he jumped at it, let's do it! We picked a good looking iceberg, right size and one that dropped straight off so that we could come nice and close without hitting it! I grabbed the bosun's chair (similar to a climbing harness) and attached it to the mainsail halyard (sailors name for a rope that hoists the sails to the top of the mast). Up I went with my two way radio in hand and my camera gear in a plastic bucket tied to the bosun's chair below me. Around my neck was my camera. In the bucket was a Canon 16-35 mm lens and a 14mm lens. Which lens worked best would be decided from my lofty perch 110 ft up at the top of the mast. I wanted to shoot wide enough to get my orange boots in the bottom of the frame and the horizon and iceberg in the top of the frame. I hung out up there and talked the captain of the boat in to position, a little to port, now a little to starbard, slowly ahead, ok stop. Hold it right here. I decided that the rectilinear Canon EF 14mm lens was the way to go. It got it all in with zero distortion. The view from up high was amazing, a true bird's eye view, a stunning sight and perspective. The captain kept the boat perfectly on station and I clicked away and got the shot. The number one question I get from visitors to my Bannisters Wharf Gallery in Newport is \xe2\x80\x9cWhose orange boots are those?\xe2\x80\x9d I always answer with, \xe2\x80\x9cWho do you think, I took the shot!\xe2\x80\x9d Camera: Canon EOS 1V
Lens: EF 14mm f/2.8L 
Aperture: f/11
ISO: 60
Shutter Speed: 1/200 sec'

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @tylerstableford | "One of the greatest things about photography is capturing magical moments, allowing us to appreciate the beauty long afterward. Along those lines, I have a personal inquiry I\xe2\x80\x99m testing in my day-to-day life: What if every moment is equally special, but our minds simply can\xe2\x80\x99t begin to process the fullness of each moment unless we slow it down or freeze it? 
Here the talented Aspen Santa Fe Ballet dancer Katie Bola\xc3\xb1os reveals a stunning display of artistry and strength. I captured Katie as part of a personal fine-art project called The Dancers. To capture high-speed moments like this in fine detail, I used the Canon EOS 5D Mark IV camera with its 30.1 megapixels with the sharp EF 85mm f/1.4L IS USM lens. I lit the scene with an overhead Elinchrom ELB 1200 light in high-speed sync mode at 1/1000th of a second to freeze the action. The overhead light helps draw the energy upward in the scene." Camera: #Canon EOS 5D Mark IV
Lens: EF 85mm f/1.4L IS USM
Aperture: f/4
ISO: 400
Shutter Speed: 1/1000 sec
Focal Length: 85mm'

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @vanessajoy | "I always get asked 'what\xe2\x80\x99s your signature photo trick?' This one is mine. Creating golden hour when that golden sun doesn\xe2\x80\x99t want to come out to play. I\xe2\x80\x99ve written a step-by-step how to in my book (check out the stories for a link to the book), but here\xe2\x80\x99s the quick version. 1: Use a long lens. 2: Use a low aperture. 3: Place your flash with a CTO gel (or 2) at a 45 degree angle behind your subject. 4: Expose like you\xe2\x80\x99re shooting natural light, then add the flash on TTL (or manual if you\xe2\x80\x99re comfortable)." b'#BehindTheShot with #CanonExplorerOfLight @susanstriplingphotography | "I\xe2\x80\x99ve always been a huge fan of multiple exposures, especially when done in camera. Canon makes it especially fun, since you can layer the images together in live view, seeing how each will lie on top of the other. This image was a quadruple exposure: one of the couple, one of a tree, and then two of smoke wafting up from a candle from their reception tables. I took the first image during their portrait session, the second while I was waiting for their ceremony to start, and the third and fourth while photographing their reception room. The image was converted to black and white in Lightroom and the edges were lightened just a touch to keep the background clean." Camera: #Canon EOS R with EF-EOS R adapter\nQuadruple exposure using three lenses: EF 135mm f/2L USM, EF 100mm f/2.8 Macro USM, and EF 24-105mm f/4L IS USM'

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @onnevanderwal | "Photographing sea turtles while free diving (no scuba tanks) with a camera in hand is one of the most amazing things I have done while exploring the Grenadines, a pristine group of islands in the Caribbean. It's hard work as I have to keep up with the turtle, position the models, hold my breath and shoot all underwater. Initially I discuss the set up with the models and hope that the turtle keeps the same pace and direction. If not, which is most of the time, I need to locate the turtle, reset and do it again and again and again. I get a good workout kicking with fins as my sole underwater propulsion as both my hands are occupied operating the camera in an underwater housing. The longer I hold my breath, the more time I have to move and be in the right position to get the perfect shot. We spent two hours in and out of the water swimming with various turtles to get this shot. Afterwards we collapsed on the deck of our anchored Moorings catamaran from exhaustion but with a grand feeling of accomplishment knowing that we got the shot!" Camera: #Canon EOS 5D Mark II 
Lens: EF 15mm F2.8 Fish Eye Lens
Aperture: f/20
ISO: 640
Shutter Speed: 1/320 sec
AquaTech housing with dome port to accommodate Canon 15mm fish eye lens field of view
(switched off autofocus and preset focus to 36\xe2\x80\x9d to prevent hunting)'

b'Find out what\'s in #CanonExplorerOfLight @greenfield_lauren\'s gear bag! | "Here is a peek at what is inside my camera bag. The bag itself is literally falling apart because it is so well-worn, but I can\xe2\x80\x99t bear to part with it because it is my \'good luck\' bag. For the goodies inside, I have been a Canon shooter for years and I always carry two bodies. I love the quick focus on the new Canon bodies. I don\xe2\x80\x99t go anywhere without my short and longer zooms 16-35mm 2.8 LII USM and 24-70mm 2.8 LII \xe2\x80\x94 those are my workhorses and the rest are \'on occasion\' but I have to carry just in case. I do use the 100mm 2.8 macro at times for details, and the 70-200mm 2.8 is great in case if I am further away from the action than I like to be. But the 16-35 and 24-70 are in my sweet spot and I love to be close to my subject which those lenses invite. I also am very attached to the Canon flashes which are almost always on my camera for a little fill. I also love to take the flash off camera and use the remote Speedlite Transmitter ST-E3-RT, especially if I have an assistant who can hold it off camera. And my limit to what I bring on the road is what I can tetris into my Think Tank Airport Security rolly including my field notebook, pen, gaff tape, \xe2\x80\x9cparty\xe2\x80\x9d gels for the flash, sunscreen, zoom recorder and mic. My feeling is that anything that gets packed in a case in cargo may not make it in time for my shoot, so I keep my Think Tank carry-on full of the absolute necessities and pack my camera bag inside the rolly so I am ready to go on arrival. Of course, the  video cameras, C300 EF, also pictured don\xe2\x80\x99t fit into my carry on and are part of a bigger film package we add on if we are also shooting for a film. But I love shooting stills as part of my films so I try to have my basic camera bag on me at all times, even when I am directing film. The wonderful thing about the Canon lenses is that they can be used interchangeably for both, and we often add on the wonderful cine lenses as well."'

b'"Nature is often referred to as 'food for the soul.' As a landscape and outdoor photographer who normally is in nature and now is not, it\xe2\x80\x99s been quite different, and even challenging at times, not having that constant exposure and the 'food for my soul' that I\xe2\x80\x99m so used to.

However, instead of being negative and focusing on what I can\xe2\x80\x99t control, I\xe2\x80\x99m doing my best to stay positive and focus on what I can control, learning, growing, and staying creative during this time.

I was inspired by several creatives, and challenged by my friends at @canonusa, to step outside of my comfort zone and use shots I\xe2\x80\x99ve taken in the outdoors as inspiration, and recreate them out of food items--the food for my soul, turned into a foodscape!

So here is the first of this photo series, called \xe2\x80\x9cFood for the Soul.\xe2\x80\x9d The first three shots were inspired by a recent photo I took back in January (photo 4). I was blown away by the size of the incredible Sequoia trees, and thought carrots might resemble the massive, orange tree trunks they are characterized by. I also used kale for the low lying branches, and dried oregano leaves for the ground cover, backlighting the structure with small lights and warm gels, to create a sunlight effect.

I used my @canonusa 5D Mark IV and EF 100mm f/2.8 macro lens, to get the perfect, up close shot I was looking for, that captured as much detail as possible. I hope you all like it, and hopefully a few more of these will follow!" - @nathanleeallen  #EOS5DMarkIV #cocreatewithcanon #foodforthesoul'

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @tylerstableford | "In this time of uncertainty, one thing is for sure: Farmers are our bedrock. I\xe2\x80\x99m certain all of us have seen dwindling supplies on grocery store shelves over the past month. For me, the limited provisions have instilled a greater appreciation for our farmers.\xe2\x81\xa3\xe2\x81\xa3
\xe2\x81\xa3\xe2\x81\xa3
I had the privilege of shooting a campaign for Walls Outdoor Goods (@wallsoutdoorgoods) this winter featuring real deal farmers on Jay Hill\xe2\x80\x99s west Texas farms. One of the highlights was capturing portraits of the farmers, as their faces and their personas are so powerful. \xe2\x81\xa3\xe2\x81\xa3
\xe2\x81\xa3\xe2\x81\xa3
Jack Zumwalt, featured here, is 62 years young and works as both a mechanic and farmer. He\xe2\x80\x99s the guy you want to know if something goes wrong with a tractor during harvest season. \xe2\x81\xa3\xe2\x81\xa3
\xe2\x81\xa3\xe2\x81\xa3
Jack is soft-spoken. He\xe2\x80\x99s kind and deeply patient. His hands are like oversized vices, even with one finger missing from a farm accident. His eyes hold the depth of the world. Capturing that radiance, and sharing it with others, is one of the things I love most about photography and cinematography.\xe2\x81\xa3\xe2\x81\xa3
\xe2\x81\xa3\xe2\x81\xa3
Jack is nowhere near social media, so I\xe2\x80\x99ll be sending him a print of this shot that I love for his memory album.\xe2\x81\xa3\xe2\x81\xa3" Camera: #Canon EOS-1D X Mark II
Lens: EF 70-200mm f/2.8L IS III USM
Aperture: f/3.5
ISO: 100
Shutter Speed: 1/320 sec
Focal Length: 70mm'

b'#BehindTheShot with #CanonExplorerOfLight @michelecelentanophotographer | "Kate, a recent high school senior was very specific about her senior portrait session. She wanted an outdoor session with lots of green in the background. She also loves backlight and wanted to highlight her blonde hair. She showed me some examples of what she had in mind and I instantly knew how I could create her dream image. We choose a gorgeous outdoor location for her session. The location is actually an organic farm with a wonderful farm to table restaurant. We scheduled her session for late in the day to ensure that beautiful light illuminating her hair. Since I knew I would be using backlight for her hair, I wanted to equally illuminate her face. I brought in a Westcott FJ 400 strobe with a beauty dish modifier. I positioned the light a bit higher than her eye level and close to the center of her face. I did not want to over power the backlight and wanted some of the hair to be over exposed to create the look she wanted. I love using foreground, middle ground and background to create depth and texture in my portraits. The wooden post and door created the foreground and the garden and beautiful light on the background created texture and depth. The gate was a bit too high for this pose so I had Kate stand on an apple box to achieve the correct subject height." Camera: #Canon EOS 5D Mark IV
Lens: EF 70-200mm f/2.8L IS USM
Aperture: f/4.5
ISO: 100
Shutter Speed: 1/200 sec
Focal Length: 140mm'

b'\xe2\x80\x9c#CanonExplorerOfLight @georgelepp here and I\xe2\x80\x99m taking over Canon\xe2\x80\x99s Instagram today. While we can\xe2\x80\x99t go to the Keukenhof Gardens this spring, I\xe2\x80\x99ve enjoyed looking through my archives for some favorite images captured with a range of Canon cameras over the last two decades. b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @tylerstableford | "American farmers help keep our country going, a fact that we are truly appreciating as we all comb the grocery stores for food during this crisis. I was thrilled to have the chance to photograph one of these incredible people, Lyndsey Haraguchi, as part of a personal fine-art portraiture series featuring American farmers.\xe2\x81\xa3
\xe2\x81\xa3
Lyndsey and her family are sixth-generation farmers who run the Ho`opulapula Haraguchi Rice Mill & Taro Farm in Hanalei, Kauai (@hanaleitaro). The historic farm provided crucial fresh provisions for American soldiers in World War II after the bombing of Pearl Harbor, and today Lyndsey and her family operate the Hanalei Taro and Juice Company in downtown Kauai. There you can sample the taro dishes, smoothies and treats right from their farm.\xe2\x81\xa3
\xe2\x81\xa3
Lyndsey has been featured in many national magazines, and she runs popular school tours and farm visits throughout the year. I captured Lyndsey harvesting taro with the iconic rainforest peaks of Hihimanu, Namolokama and Mamalahoa towering behind her. If you find yourself on Kauai once the world starts moving again, stop by for one of her farm tours!\xe2\x81\xa3
\xe2\x81\xa3
I captured this image with the Canon EOS R camera and the RF 28-70mm f/2.0 lens during a family trip this winter, while our kids held a reflector for fill light.\xe2\x81\xa3" Camera: #Canon EOS R
Lens: RF 28-70mm F2 L USM
Aperture: f/4.0
ISO: 100
Shutter Speed: 1/400 sec
Focal Length: 36mm'

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @tylerstableford | "I am so thankful for our farmers during this time of uncertainty\xe2\x80\x94they are the cornerstone of our food supply. It has been a real honor to get to know Jay Hill this winter. Jay is a renaissance west Texas farmer who defies boundaries. To start with, he did something almost nobody does: He went IN to farming in his 30s from a traditional working career. Farms are places that most people are quick to leave these days, due to unstable commodity markets, climate volatility and endless hours of work. \xe2\x81\xa3
\xe2\x81\xa3
Jay is committed to sustainable agriculture. He and his team raise a dozen crops and livestock over two states in west Texas and New Mexico. The farms grow everything from cotton to chili peppers, from lettuce to alfalfa \xe2\x80\x94 he even has a commercial vineyard for good measure.\xe2\x81\xa3
\xe2\x81\xa3
I had the joy of photographing and filming with Jay this winter in his hometown of Dell City, Texas for a Walls Outdoor Goods (@wallsoutdoorgoods) workwear campaign. Jay is a social media icon in the agriculture world and an ambassador for the Walls clothing brand.\xe2\x81\xa3
\xe2\x81\xa3
I captured Jay at dusk in front of his cotton pickers, just as his team was wrapping up the day\xe2\x80\x99s harvest. Jay is committed to sustainable cotton farming and to revitalizing American clothing manufacturing.\xe2\x81\xa3
\xe2\x81\xa3
Jay speaks around the world, discussing new agriculture techniques. 'Climate change is already upon us,' he says. 'If you can\xe2\x80\x99t prove that what you\xe2\x80\x99re doing is bettering the environment, you\xe2\x80\x99re going to feel the repercussions.'
\xe2\x81\xa3
Learn more about Jay at @hilljay45 \xe2\x80\x94 and he\xe2\x80\x99s also featured in countless articles and podcasts online. He\xe2\x80\x99ll change the way you think about modern agriculture. Thanks, Jay, for being such a proud and honorable voice for farming!\xe2\x81\xa3" Camera: #Canon EOS-1D X Mark II
Lens: EF 24-70mm f/2.8L II USM
Aperture: f/5.6
ISO: 160
Shutter Speed: 1/160 sec
Focal Length: 24mm'

b'"We were getting our first warm weekend after winter in upstate New York and temperatures were in the mid to upper sixties throughout the day on Lake George. What had been an ice covered section of lake a week prior was now mostly open water. The day was nearing its end and the sky was a patchwork of blue and clouds at varying elevations. It was the perfect opportunity to get out in the kayak for my first paddling excursion of the season. I was treated to one of the most gorgeous sunset skies I could have ever asked for that evening. The lake was also perfectly calm, no boats in it. I had the whole lake to myself. Reflections were perfect. Here's the result." #MyCanonStory

Photo Credit: @wadamczakphoto

b'"It had been a long day driving around Yellowstone photographing the awesome wildlife and beautiful landscapes. While on our way back to Montana we drove through a severe thunderstorm with some of the darkest skies I have ever seen. Just as we were driving out of the entrance to the park, the skies towards the west opened up, the sun lit up Roosevelt Arch, and a beautiful double rainbow appeared...it felt so unreal! I grabbed my Canon 5D Mark IV and managed to capture this four shot panorama handheld before it slowly faded away. Definitely one of my most memorable #CanonMemories." :rainbow:Thanks for sharing and being a part of #TeamCanon, @steve_lasley_photography. :camera:Camera: #Canon 5D Mark IV'

b'#BehindTheShot with #CanonExplorerOfLight @davidhumekennerly | "On September 21, 2012 the Space Shuttle Endeavor, riding atop a 747 Shuttle Carrier, flew over Santa Monica on its final approach to Los Angeles International Airport. It was the last journey of the Endeavor, and its final destination would be the California Science Center. I\xe2\x80\x99ve photographed two shuttle launches, the first in 1998. The second liftoff was in 2007 to the International Space Station. My only regret was that I didn\xe2\x80\x99t photograph more, they were both visually and emotionally stunning! When I heard that the Endeavor was going to be landing in Los Angeles, I had to see it, and figure out how to get a good photo of the event. I really wanted to make an image that said \xe2\x80\x9cCalifornia.\xe2\x80\x9d I\xe2\x80\x99ve always loved the area around the Santa Monica Pier, so when it was announced that the Shuttle would fly over it, I figured that would be my bingo moment.

That morning I got down to the beach early to scout out a place to catch the action. They had been pretty specific about the flight path, so I found a good spot that I thought would work, but it came in higher and from a different angle. The good news was that there was a young woman nearby working out on the rings that made excellent foreground. She was a terrific gymnast, so I started shooting the shuttle as she flew through the air with the greatest of ease. The magic moment came as she looked up at the shuttle, and it was perfect. California Girl and Space Shuttle. What more could you want? And there was even a bonus element, a yellow parasail at the bottom left of the frame. This is one of my favorite photos, probably because it has nothing to do with politics!" Photo Credit: David Hume Kennerly/ Center for Creative Photography/University of Arizona
Camera: #Canon EOS 5D Mark II
Lens: EF 24-105mm f/4L IS USM
Aperture: f/11
ISO: 200
Shutter Speed: 1/640 sec
Focal Length: 45mm'

b'"A memory that really stands out to me, and has been bringing me a lot joy during this difficult time, is from a wonderful week that my family and I spent in the Great Smoky Mountains National Park this past Fall. Never had we seen such variety and expansiveness of colors. One of my favorite moments of the trip was witnessing (and photographing) this incredible sunrise at the Oconaluftee Valley Overlook. We had already been impressed by the mountains upon mountains of Fall colors, but this sunrise was the icing on the cake. There was a lot of cloud cover that morning, and I wasn\'t sure what the sky was going to do, but then suddenly it started to fill with the rich yellows, purples, and pinks of pre-dawn, and then finally the sun peaked out from behind the clouds ever so briefly, creating this mesmerizing scene. One of the most beautiful things I\'ve ever seen\xe2\x80\xa6" Thank you for sharing your #CanonMemories with us, @ninamayerritchie\nCamera :camera:: #Canon EOS 6D Mark II\n...Have an uplifting story and photo to share with us? :red_heart_selector: Tap the link in our bio to submit your #CanonMemories!'

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @darrellgulin | "I raised this trio of Leopard Lacewing Butterflies, Cethosia cyane, and photographed them in my kitchen. I've had the USDA permit in the past allowing me to raise and photograph some tropical butterflies. To keep all three of these butterflies in focus, I used f/16 for greater depth of field. Also I placed the three butterflies on the flower, and worked really hard on keeping them on the same focal plane. Like a butterfly whisperer, I would place them on the flower over and over until I got just the right composition.  The background is an out of focus print taped on the window behind the butterflies. I made sure that it was with matte paper and of course printed on my Canon PIXMA PRO-100 printer." Camera: #Canon EOS-1Ds Mark II
Lens: EF 180mm f/3.5L Macro USM
Aperture: f/16
ISO: 200
Shutter Speed: 1/8 sec
Focal Length: 180mm'

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @ricksammonphotography | "Happy Hour at the Watering Hole. I captured this scene from an underground 'hide' at a watering hole in Botswana. 
This photograph illustrates five important photo techniques: 
1) The name of the game is to fill the frame - if you want an image with impact. 
2) Gesture is key in wildlife photography, and the elephant on the left has a wonderful gesture. 
3) When it comes to composition, the rule of odds (an odd number of subjects) usually wins out over having an even number of subjects in a photograph. 
4) Reflections are wonderful in photographs. 
5) Separation is key when photographing multiple subjects; notice how the elephants' heads are clearly separated from each other." Camera: #Canon 5DS
Lens: EF 24-105mm f/4L IS II USM
Aperture: f/7.1
ISO: 250
Shutter Speed: 1/640 sec
Focal Length: 43mm'

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @davidhumekennerly | "I\xe2\x80\x99ve photographed a lot of extraordinary things in my career, but the total eclipse of the sun on August 21, 2017 is definitely in my top five! The trick was to be in the middle of the path of totality, and out of the way of the clouds. I chose Monmouth, Oregon in the Willamette Valley to take the shot, and it paid off.

During a total solar eclipse, the moon passes between earth and the sun, blocking out the sun\xe2\x80\x99s light. At that moment the white corona, which is the outer layer of the sun\xe2\x80\x99s atmosphere, can clearly be seen surrounding the eclipsed sun.  It was a spectacular sight. A bonus was to also document a solar prominence on the top and right side of the sun. A prominence is a bright, fiery, gaseous event that emanates from the sun\xe2\x80\x99s surface, often in the shape of a loop. A typical prominence can extend more than 62,000 miles from the sun\xe2\x80\x99s surface, and is ten times the size of earth. Some reach more than 300,000 miles into space.

To accomplish this photograph I used a Canon 5DS R with a Canon 800mm f/5.6 lens coupled with a 1.4 Extender II, making it 1120mm. The ISO was 320, the exposure 1/320 at f/8. It would not have been possible to see the prominence without this long lens.

If I\xe2\x80\x99m lucky enough to witness another solar eclipse, I will choose the Canon 1200mm with the 1.4 extender. That will give me a 1680mm look at another amazing celestial event! My intention is to photograph the April 8, 2024 eclipse from Burlington, Vermont." Photo Credit: David Hume Kennerly/ Center for Creative Photography/University of Arizona
Camera: #Canon EOS 5DS R
Lens: EF 800mm f/5.6L IS USM/Extender EF 1.4x II
Aperture: f/8
ISO: 320
Shutter Speed: 1/320 sec
Focal Length: 1120mm'

b'"Look who's learning photography! :camera_with_flash: (swipe to see her reaction:smiling_face_with_heart-eyes:) I hope everyone is doing well and staying home (if possible) during this crazy time! I decided to use my extra time at home to introduce Lolo to photography! :raising_hands_light_skin_tone: She is 3.5 years old so of course she can\xe2\x80\x99t technically work the camera but she is old enough to point and click! She used my Canon #EOSM50 in AUTO. The EOS M50 is very compact and light weight so she can easily handle it. This was honestly one of the most fun shoots I\xe2\x80\x99ve done lately! Watching her excitement as she pressed the shutter and then saw her image pop up on the LCD screen was precious! She was SO proud of herself!
TIP#1 - Toddlers like to feel like they are in control so I let her set up her own shoot! She chose the outfits, the high chair prop, and the bubbles! I just directed her to the pretty light:sparkles: TIP #2 - Do not put your camera in a compromising position ... Notice I let her do this on a bed so if she dropped the camera it was okay! TIP #3 - Have FUN! Make memories together, foster creativity, build confidence in your little one by letting them take the reins!" - @taraherron_photography
#CoCreateWithCanon

b'#BehindTheShot with #CanonExplorerOfLight @49ersofficialphotog | "Chapman\xe2\x80\x99s Peak, Cape Town South Africa. 
The year was 2011 and I was on assignment for a client. I came across a site that was so beautiful and captivating. That place was Chapman\xe2\x80\x99s Peak. Along our drive up the coastline of Cape Town, we stopped at the peak to take it all in and enjoy what was in front of us. The countryside in this region of the world is simply breathtaking and absolutely a once in a lifetime experience. 
I flew over 36 hours from San Francisco to New York to Johannesburg to make it to my destination of Cape Town. For me, it was the longest flight I\xe2\x80\x99ve ever taken. But as I was looking forward to this trip, I anticipated that it would be the trip of a lifetime. People often ask me to name out of all of the places that I have traveled which one stands out the most, and I always rate South Africa by far as number one on my list. 
This is my Canon story." Camera: #Canon EOS 5D Mark II
Lens: EF 16-35mm f/2.8L USM
Aperture: f/5.6
ISO: 200
Shutter Speed: 1/1000 sec
Focal Length: 16mm'

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @michelecelentanophotographer | "I wanted to control every aspect of this image. I imagined this exact image in my mind before I created it. I found this wedding dress at a local thrift shop, I loved the lace skirt but the bodice of the dress was awful.  I cut the lace skirt from the bodice and then let it soak in a large bucket of coffee for nearly 3 days. I hand painted the background the exact color I wanted to match the tones of the skirt. Then I stained the wood chair that Shelby is standing on. The top of her dress was part of her princess Halloween costume. The color of her dress was not quite the tone I wanted and I simply adjusted it in post processing. There is something really beautiful and satisfying about creating an image and controlling every detail from capture to post processing. I used one strobe light camera left." b'#BehindTheShot with #CanonExplorerOfLight @darrellgulin |"One of my top bucket list locations, for many years, was Japan in the winter with the Japanese Cranes, Whooping Swans, Stellar Fish Eagles and Snow Monkeys. Finally Joe Van Os Photo Safaris offered me the chance to lead a workshop to Japan in the winter of February 2016. It did not disappoint, becoming one of my 5 top favorite Wildlife locations. I always wanted to photograph the Red-crowned crane so this is why I picked this image to share. Besides when I was photographing the immature Red-crowned crane chasing after the Whooping Swans it just made me smile. This image was taken at the Tsurui Mura Crane Reserve, in Hokkaido Japan. Lens of choice was the Canon EF 100-400mm f/4.5-5.6L IS II USM, 1.4x III extender, and Canon's EOS 7D Mark II camera. This combination would allow me to photograph up to almost 900mm. The key  to getting a sharp image was Image Stabilization and a fast shutter speed." Camera: #Canon EOS 7D Mark II

b'Find out what's inside @larajadephotography's gear bag! | "So many photographers ask what gear I use & I wanted to share what\xe2\x80\x99s in my current camera bag! Since I have a lot of time on my hands I thought I\xe2\x80\x99d create some content that would give you more of an insight into the creative side of my business. 
In the industry I am in there is a level of importance to have gear that fits my client\xe2\x80\x99s requests - this is why I own a few bodies & a variety of lenses. I like to have backup cameras in my gear bag - just in case! It also helps if a client requires a second photographer or an assistant to shoot extra content on set (which often happens!). Fashion & beauty work demand different techniques. For fashion - my most used lens is the Canon 85mm f/1.2. For beauty - I use the Canon 100mm Macro f/2.8 lens.
Let me talk you through the gear - see below!

Canon EOS R body + 28-70mm f/2.0 lens

Canon 5D MKIV body

b'Find out what's in #CanonExplorerOfLight @49ersofficialphotog's gear bag! | "Well, are you ready for this list of gear? During the season you will find me out there working with 5 Canon EOS bodies with an array of lenses to capture all of the behind the senses, action, portraits, entertainment, etc. I often get asked why so many cameras and lenses & the answer is that I have to cover so many different things prior to game time. My responsibilities cover far more than just game action as I have to photograph for ownership, marketing, partnerships, sales, foundation, community relations and of course game day which will cover locker room, pregame, introductions, sideline, action & don\xe2\x80\x99t forget about post game. In order for me to complete the task at hand you have to be ready for any & all situations with a vast number of lenses at your disposal. 
I\xe2\x80\x99ve had every Canon camera in their flagship line since digital was introduced in 1996 and I am now getting ready for the 2020 season working with the Canon EOS-1D X Mark III cameras which I feel is a \xe2\x80\x9cGame Changer\xe2\x80\x9d in the Canon line. With Canon's new CMOS sensor & an updated DIGIC X image processor the tracking, detail, image quality, enhanced dynamic range, and color are incredible as well as a number of enhancements which make this camera first class. Also adding in their new WFT-E9 transmitter for wireless transmission, it just keeps getting better.

So, let\xe2\x80\x99s take a look at all of my game day gear below to give you an idea of what I use during the game. Also, you may ask how I carry all of the equipment at one time, and the answer is I have two assistants with me at all times.

b'#BehindTheShot with #CanonExplorerOfLight @dorn.bruce, DGA | "I love taking photos but I really love making photos! Coming up with a good idea, however, is always an adventure. These images, from my most recent self-assignment, \xe2\x80\x9cThe Adventures of Bad Apple and Ducky,\xe2\x80\x9d offer a glimpse into the methods behind my madness. 
Inspiration: The inspiration for this shoot was a teensy model tank built by a friend. The instant I saw it I knew I had to use it as a \xe2\x80\x9cHanging Miniature\xe2\x80\x9d; a forced-perspective, in-camera, special effect technique widely used in pre-digital Hollywood. 
Ideation: With this technique in mind, I got the idea of creating my own comic book! 
Preparation: I wanted a strong female protagonist so I recruited Natasha, an imaginative cosplay model who can act. After considering my storyline I sketched a few concept frames, went shopping for some military props, discovered Ducky the Doll, and built my character a bazooka out of PVC pipe and scrap aluminum. Low cost and loads of fun!

Execution: I twisted an EF 24-70mm F4L IS zoom onto my 50.6MP Canon EOS 5Ds R, tucked the tank in my pocket, and off to the desert we went. Knowing that I had to leave room for my actress to act, I composed my frames with just the right amount of negative space. I set my camera to Manual Mode, Daylight WB, ISO 400, F/16, 1/85th. Two weeks later, after a quick stop at a Halloween shop to buy wound-and-bruise make-up, I met my actress at a tiny rental studio in downtown LA. As the model did her make-up, I set up three full-spectrum LED lights. My key-light was set to 5600K WB and my two kickers were orange. Once again, the Canon EOS 5Ds R carried my EF 24-70mm F/4L IS and was set to ISO 800, F/6.3, 1/100th.

Editing: My model\xe2\x80\x99s poses were visually-resized and layered over the desert backgrounds until I was happy with the look. Flames, smoke, dust, and tracer fire were added in post." Follow @dorn.bruce and check out earlier chapters of \xe2\x80\x9cThe Adventures of Bad Apple & Ducky.\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'"This was on my first trip to Upper Lena Lake, with my little brother-in-law. We went woefully unprepared and ran out of water two thirds of the way up. We started to cramp and get light headed, well before it was time to rest or turn back. After we painfully reached the lake at the top of the 7.5 mile trail, we enjoyed this amazing view. We trekked down and fortunately were gifted water by passing hikers, as well as resorted to refilling our old bottles with no filter from natural mountain spring water. It was risky to say the least, but in the end we survived and made it home. It was a gorgeous hike and a trip we will never forget." #MyCanonStory

b'Find out what's in #CanonExplorerOfLight @damianstroh's gear bag! | "When you talk about 'what\xe2\x80\x99s in my bag' it\xe2\x80\x99s more like 'what isn\xe2\x80\x99t in my bag?' Each job is a little different but there are items that recur in almost every shoot. I carry two or three camera bodies, depending on the assignment. My camera of choice is the Canon EOS-1D X Mark II, until the new EOS-1D X Mark III is in my hands. Like a lot of photographers I use the 'Holy Trinity' of Canon lenses, a 16mm-35mm f/2.8, 24mm-70mm f/2.8, and the workhorse 70mm-200mm f2.8. Since a lot of my work involves sports the Canon 400mm f/2.8 is a staple. I always have a TC 1.4 in the bag. I use it with both the 400mm f/2.8 and occasionally with the 70mm-200mm.

The rest of the stuff that goes out the door is common sense: extra batteries, gaffers tape, cards, portable flash, chargers, lens cloths, and if I\xe2\x80\x99m out with a long lens I bring a monopod. I try to remember sun tan lotion, and I try to keep my family close at heart with some photos tucked away.

I pack up all this stuff in a Think Tank Airport Security Version 3 and a Think Tank Shape Shifter backpack. All the little stuff fits into a Mountainsmith Tour Classic waist pack."'

b'Photos and video by #CanonExplorerOfLight @dorn.bruce | "As a Canon Explorer of Light, I recently had a chance to work with a pre-release Canon EOS-1D X Mark III and it is spectacular. 
The EOS-1D X Mark III offers terrific latitude, amazing autofocus, robust construction, and blazingly fast capture. I rate it as the best stills camera that Canon has ever produced. And then there\xe2\x80\x99s the video side. I know that some \xe2\x80\x9cstills only\xe2\x80\x9d shooters have absolutely no interest in video but those who don\xe2\x80\x99t investigate \xe2\x80\x9cvideo for frame grabs\xe2\x80\x9d are only cheating themselves. 
Let me explain. The Canon EOS-1D X Mark III, in Video Mode, is able to record up to 5.5K Raw video at speeds as high as 60 fps. Each of those Raw video frames is a quality still image just waiting to be extracted. If you\xe2\x80\x99re in a hurry, you can extract video frames right in the camera. Or, you can wait until post and access everything that Raw capture has to offer. Motorsports, wildlife, wedding work, and news coverage \xe2\x80\x93 these are just a few photographic specialties that can benefit from this technology. I keep my personal cameras in this Video Mode, \xe2\x80\x9cjust in case\xe2\x80\x9d something newsworthy pops up in front of me.

It\xe2\x80\x99s easy! Switch to Video Mode and use the same shutter-speeds, apertures, and ISO settings that you normally would. With recent Canon DSLR cameras you\xe2\x80\x99ll be composing via the cameras\xe2\x80\x99 LCD screen. The Canon EOS R allows you to compose on the LCD or thru the camera\xe2\x80\x99s EVF. Either way, by choosing to shoot video-for-stills, you\xe2\x80\x99ll be unleashing still photo capture speeds that are otherwise unattainable. Yep, the files will be in the 16x9 proportion but that size and shape is perfect for electronic publishing. 
Check out this traditional 20 megapixel still frame, a few 5.5K frame grabs, and the cool video clip we produced with the awesome EOS-1D X Mark III." Project: \xe2\x80\x9cMisery\xe2\x80\x9d 
Client: @buddyblazeguitars 
Producer/Director/Editor: @stevie_thunder
DoP: @dorn.bruce
Muscle: @mykk.hannan
Talent: @dylanjd11
Music: @stormofperception'

Freezing the water with a fast shutter speed is never a problem, I set out to show the speed & power of Pipeline by slowing down my settings. Shooting with such a slow shutter speed while treading water within a wave, focusing and composing the image, and holding the camera water-housing above the surface is no easy feat. But thanks to the amazing 14 frames per second on the EOS-1D X Mark II, I am able to shoot loose and edit tight to deliver this moment of the raw power of Pipeline." Camera: #Canon EOS-1D X Mark II

b'"This was one of my first shots of the new year, having been sick for the past few weeks, so I figured a windy, winter day at Lake Tahoe would be a good first capture. However, since I hadn't been out for awhile, I was a bit rusty. While I was setting up and readjusting my tripod, I forgot that my wireless remote was in my hand (I was also wearing gloves, so I didn't have that tactile feeling of the remote in my hand). As I moved a leg, the remote just slipped out of my grip, crashed with a delicate sound of a nearby boulder, then splashed helplessly into the waves of Lake Tahoe. I did give a dramatic 'noooooo!' as it happened, but it was a lost cause. I did however manage to snap this shot, which I think makes up for it. Of course, I had to use a 2-second timer at that point, but it's all good." #MyCanonStory

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @stephenjohnsonphoto from his Life Form Series | "This photograph was a particular challenge as I composed it without being able to fully preview the final look. The nearest part of the plant reached so far forward that I could not tell exactly what the final photograph would look like with everything in reasonable focus. I was quite pleased with the results.

This photograph is an eight image focus stack to achieve a good depth of field from front to back. Each photograph was hand-focused after a careful rehearsal of the focus range and distances needed for the set. The exposed set was focus-stacked as rendered 16 bit tiffs in Helicon Focus software." b'Take a look inside #CanonExplorerOfLight @charlesglatzer's gear bag! | "Whenever you visit Africa it can prove extremely dusty. To reduce dust on the sensors and interiors of cameras and lenses I try never to change lenses once assembled on location. This typically requires three separate camera bodies attached to a variety of focal lengths to cover as many bases as possible.

I choose the EF EOS R mirrorless body for use with my two wider lenses (RF 24-105, EF 70-200 f/2.8 IS), as these are typically used for my animalscape type images which benefit from more megapixels and a bit slower moving of AF focus points within the viewfinder. I use the EOS-1D X Mark III for all fast moving wildlife, the speed of AF acquisition, lock, and tracking is mind blowingly accurate! Moreover, low lighting conditions along with the need for fast shutter speeds require high ISOs. The image quality at ISO 6400 and above is Canon\xe2\x80\x99s best yet. 
My three zoom lenses cover a very large focal range. I am seamlessly covered from 24-560mm. The EF 600mm adds longer coverage when subjects are at distance or I require greater magnification at closer distances such as with smaller birds or tight portraits. Of course, the EF 14.X III adds another 1.4X magnification while maintaining my primary lens minimum focus distance. 
It\xe2\x80\x99s a lot of gear, but remember this is my livelihood, and for many this may be a once in a lifetime venture." Gear List
