b'Behind the shot with #CanonExplorerOfLight @Vanessajoy | "Every once in a while my dream comes true and a publication asks me to do a shoot that's just for the magazine! This was one of those skin-pinching moments and I wanted to give them everything they expected (a bright, natural light look), but find a way to do a little something extra too. :sparkles: After seeing this dress, I knew we needed to play a bit! It was right after sunset so we were losing light fast, and I wanted to give the dress a bit of flirty movement, ensure that all of the details were crisp and the model was in focus, but separate her from the background using lens compression, a shallower f-stop and a rim light. 
I had my assistant walking with the model (Nikki), pointing a Profoto B2 with an OCF beauty dish at the model as she walked towards me and turned left to right. In the back, I placed a Profoto B1 on a light stand with a CTO gel to match the warm light given off by the lanterns on the chapel wall. I used TTL to get my initial flash power settings, and then switched to manual to adjust.

This is my favorite shot because of how the dressed flared and her expression. Some of the other photos had slightly better light on the model's face because she was towards the light a bit more, but this is still my favorite because, for me, expression is top priority. I stick by this priority in most of my shooting because my non-photographer clients don't see light and posing the way that I do, and don't know the difference between good and great. But they do know the difference between good and great expressions and eye-catching dress twirls. The magazine loved this shot, and the others I took that day, so much that they ended up over 14 pages in the magazine. Success!" Canon #Canon EOS-1D X Mark II

b'Find out what\xe2\x80\x99s in #CanonExplorerOfLight @roberto_photo\xe2\x80\x99s spicy gear bag! | \xe2\x80\x9cIn my teaching career, especially during my creativeLIVE classes a few years ago, I used to always say to add some hot sauce to your work! If you have bland broccoli, it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t taste like much. But add spice to that broccoli, and suddenly it hits you! You feel something! That\xe2\x80\x99s the same way it is in photography. Once you push yourself to add a something special to the image, it makes you feel something. It draws you in, and it makes you want more. Now, as a joke to show me how they are \xe2\x80\x98spicing it up,\xe2\x80\x99 people have been bringing me hot sauces from all over the world. Therefore, people that know me well, associate me with spicy, chilies, or hot sauce :hot_pepper: So push yourself and add some spice to your photography!\xe2\x80\x9c'

b'#BehindTheShot with #CanonExplorerOfLight @georgelepp | \xe2\x80\x9cNot even a super telephoto will get you a head-and-shoulder portrait of a wild bird in the field. You can try to sneak up on them to get that close-up, but be prepared for rejection as they just move farther away. As I have repeatedly advised, getting close to birds in the wild typically requires that the photographer employ a photo blind to obscure the human form and movement while being careful to protect the subjects themselves. \nRecently, I used my house as a blind. I noticed that birds were coming to a feeder located close to a window, and that the light being reflected on the outside of the window obscured the birds\xe2\x80\x99 view of movement inside. I knew that I had an unusual chance to capture intimate portraits, so I put together the perfect rig for the job. First, the new Canon EOS 90D with 32.5 MP of resolution and its APS-C sensor with its 1.6x crop factor that helps to fill the frame. Next, the Canon EF 100-400mm f4.5-5.6L Mark II lens that gives great close-ups and focuses to 3.2 feet. Then I had one more trick up my sleeve, and that was a 1.4x extender on the 400mm, all giving me an equivalent focal length of 896mm, perfect for larger birds such as jays, from a distance of about three feet. Or, for smaller species such as hummingbirds, a 2x extender achieving 1280mm at the same range. With the gear at hand, all I had to do was configure a lighting setup that would shoot through two panes of glass, balance the shady foreground with the sunny background, and get me to an aperture of f/22 for maximum depth of field. I found that solution in the Canon Speedlite 600EX-RT flash concentrated by 3 f/stops with a MagMod MagBeam attachment. \nThen all I had to do was wait for the birds to arrive. They did! Here are some results.\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'"It snowed Friday night, it\xe2\x80\x99s the first time I\xe2\x80\x99ve been in town for snow. I love lousy weather, especially in winter and this fit the bill. It was snowing pretty hard and just below freezing so the snow was melting as soon as it landed on me. There was a lot of wind, which made for great drama, but it was kinda uncomfortable. This was my first stop on Friday and it turned out to be my favorite image from the evening, it was just at the end of blue hour. I used a wide aperture and a speed light on manual to capture the bokeh snow in the image. I wanted to freeze the motion of the train so I needed a pretty fast shutter speed." #MyCanonStory

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @georgelepp | \xe2\x80\x9cAmong Central Oregon\xe2\x80\x99s abundant wildlife subjects, river otters can be quite challenging to photograph. They\xe2\x80\x99re shy, constantly in motion, and able to disappear underwater in a flash. To give myself the best odds for success, I put together a setup designed for speed and reach: the Canon EOS 90D camera (10 fps and 1.6x crop factor), EF 600mm f/4L III lens,\xc2\xa0both the EF 1.4x III and EF 2x III extenders, and a sturdy tripod. When I spotted an otter eating a catfish among the cattails on the opposite bank, I used the EF 600mm lens with the EF 2x III extender (1920mm on the 90D) to get a full-frame capture at 1/250 sec, f/11, and ISO 1600. Later, I watched a group of three otters playing on an ice-covered portion of the small lake. From a closer vantage point, I opted for the EF 600mm III lens with the 1.4x III extender and stopped the action at 1/2000 sec. @ f/8 and ISO 800. It was an \xe2\x80\x98otterly\xe2\x80\x99 fantastic day!\xe2\x80\x9d'

b'Check out what\'s in #CanonExplorerOfLight @tylerstableford\'s gear bag! | "When I am shooting ice climbing in the mountains, I aim to carry the minimal amount of equipment in my bags so that I can climb and keep up with the athletes \xe2\x80\x94 but it also needs to be the best gear that can capture the best images! The Canon EOS-1D X Mark III and the SanDisk 512gb Extreme Pro CFexpress cards are my go-tos for high-speed shooting. When I\xe2\x80\x99m hanging on a rope photographing or filming a climber, I am not as mobile as I would be on the ground, so I use zoom lenses that let me reframe the scenes quickly. My favorite lenses are the 11-24mm f/4, 16-35mm f/2.8, 24-70mm f/2.8, and 70-200mm f/2.8. I\xe2\x80\x99ll often leave one of the two widest lenses at the base, but I like to have both with me until I evaluate what the scenario will require. This photo shows a small portion of the climbing gear I bring on a shoot, including crampons, harness, ice tools, ascenders, rope, and a Garmin Inreach Mini for emergencies and satellite texts (fortunately I\xe2\x80\x99ve only had to use it for texting with my family when out of cell range). My camera gear all goes in my trusted Think Tank Photo Speed Racer 2 shoulder bag, which I can wear buckled on my hip or slung around my shoulder for quick access; and it doesn\xe2\x80\x99t obstruct my harness. The rest of the climbing equipment goes on my harness."'

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @jeremycowart | \xe2\x80\x9cDigital photography gets better and better. Cameras get more and more reliable and consistent. The quality is insane. But reliability and consistency can also make an artist like me really bored. I\xe2\x80\x99m always dreaming of ways to figure out how to make digital photography weird and unpredictable without having to rely on heavy post-production. I\xe2\x80\x99m certainly a Photoshop user but I try to only use it when absolutely necessary like light skin retouching. Nothing else.
.
So when I was hired to create this image for an album package, the artist wanted something ethereal\xe2\x80\xa6 something that looked like it was from another planet. For some reason my mind went to a place of him being submerged in another world\xe2\x80\xa6 liquid or bubbles almost.
.
So I had the idea to use the TTV technique which means \xe2\x80\x9cthrough the viewfinder\xe2\x80\x9d to shoot through an old waist-level viewfinder camera that I found online. Here\xe2\x80\x99s the fun part: I wanted the lens to bubble up on the viewfinder camera so I set it on fire. I literally took a lighter to the lens in my kitchen and let the old vintage glass burn a little bit and burn and bubble up. The effect was exactly what I was hoping for.
.
Then on our actual photoshoot, I took my Canon EOS 1DX Mark II and a 100mm 2.8 macro lens and I stood high on a ladder so that I could lean over and photograph the artist with my Canon DSLR through the burned vintage camera.
.
I had just one light with a large octabank lighting him from the left and wha-la. Some light RAW processing later and there ya have it. No textures added or photoshop work done.\xe2\x80\x9d .
Camera: #Canon EOS 1DX Mark II
Lens: EF 100mm f/2.8L
Aperture: f/11
ISO: 400
Shutter Speed: 1/125 sec
Focal Length: 100mm .

Follow #CanonExplorerOfLight @jeremycowart for more experimental portrait techniques. He\xe2\x80\x99s doing crazy things with Canon projectors and learning new tricks daily.'

To help me make quick decisions and avoid switching lenses in busy environments - I often use a zoom lens." Camera: #Canon EOS 5D Mark IV

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @jeremycowart | \xe2\x80\x9cI\xe2\x80\x99ve been experimenting a ton in the studio lately with my Canon 5Ds and Canon projectors. I\xe2\x80\x99ve always said 'the more you learn technically, the more you can achieve creatively.' As photographers, we tend to think we can just survive off our creativity alone. But I\xe2\x80\x99ve found that the more you read those manuals and learn all the intricate stuff, you can pull off intricate imagery. My ideas always come to life after I learn a little more about my camera or my lights. This image has a little shutter drag, combined with a texture I projected on the wall behind her. All effects were achieved in camera, even the light flares. I did some light RAW processing and tweaked the white balance and added contrast and then we did some light skin retouching. I can\xe2\x80\x99t recommend enough that photographers throw all the rules out the window and just allow themselves to play and explore new ideas. You never know where they may lead you." b'#BehindTheShot with #CanonExplorerOfLight @davidbergman | "I spent nearly ten years traveling the world as Bon Jovi's tour photographer and had the privilege of documenting hundreds of the band's shows. To keep things interesting - photographically speaking - I challenged myself to make new and unique images every night. Prior to the show, drummer Tico Torres would meticulously wrap his calloused hands with strips of gaffers tape before putting on his drumming gloves. One night, I got in close and snapped a high speed burst of around 30 frames as he went through his routine in the dressing room. I converted this image to black and white so that the color wouldn't be a distraction, and all you see are the details in hands that have produced 35 years of rock and roll history." b'Photo by @babaktafreshi | "Canon lent me the new astrophotography #EOSRa to test out on a recent project in New Zealand. The parting clouds and setting Milky Way in this chilly midnight of Queenstown, provided a dynamic scene on the shore of Lake Wakatipu. Using the EOS Ra with the 15-35mm f2.8 RF lens I set up for a time lapse sequence. Looking toward the south, in the sky the galactic core is disappearing on the right while the Southern Cross and Carina nebula are rising on the left. Almost 800 shots are captured in this 2.5 hours long time lapse. One single LP-E6N battery in the camera lasted for about 1400 shots on that night which is impressive to me for a mirrorless system." #eosra #astrophotography #nightscape #timelapse #newzealand

b'Check out what\'s in #CanonExplorerOfLight @onnevanderwal\'s gear bag! | \xe2\x80\x9dThis is my typical set up for a commercial or editorial assignment where I need to travel by plane, train or automobile. Everything except the tripod and the waterproof housing fit in to a roller bag that is carried onboard and stowed in the overhead bin on the plane. The Aquatech waterproof housing and a tripod are stowed in a checked 85L waterproof roller bag with my clothes, chargers and other gear. I have two camera systems in my bag as I am in the middle of switching over from my Canon DSLR system to Canon\xe2\x80\x99s mirrorless R system. A Canon EOS 5D Mark IV body with booster is used on the Canon EF 200-400 1.4x F4 IS L lens. Then I have two Canon EOS R mirrorless cameras that are used with the 3 new RF lenses; RF 15-35 F2.8 IS L, RF 24-70 F2.8 IS L and the RF 70-200 F2.8 IS L lenses. So while shooting from a helicopter or chase boat I can have the 24-70 on body #1, the 70-200 on body #2 and the 200-400 1.4X on body # 3, the 5D giving me a fabulous range of 24-560 (1.4x engaged on the 200-400 1.4 lens) over the three camera bodies and no lens changing is needed. Having 3 bodies is crucial while out on the water to keep things dry and not missing a beat in the action, you are always ready to go!"'

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @davidbergman | "Something I teach in my #shootfromthepit workshops is that you need to separate yourself from all the other photographers covering the same events. Clients have no reason to hire you if you're making pictures they can easily get from someone else. As the tour photographer for country superstar, Luke Combs, I use my access to set up remote cameras in various locations, just like I did when I covered sporting events. I occasionally attach one to a lighting truss while our crew is setting it up on the ground. The camera (and safety cable!) raises into the air with the lights, and I never quite know exactly what I'm going to get. On this night in Sacramento, the lighting hit at just the right moment to create an interesting shadow. It's safe to say I'm the only one who made an image like this." Camera: #Canon EOS 5D Mark IV

Aperture: f/5.6

Focal Length: 24mm'

b'#BehindTheShot of #CanonExplorerOfLight @adam_jones_photo | "This sunrise image from Grand Teton National Park, was made the last week of September, 2019 and fall colors were at peak in the park.\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0I was actually on a private workshop with a client and we hired a local guide to show us some of his favorite scenic locations and wildlife areas.\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0At first the sky didn\xe2\x80\x99t look that great, but as the sun rose, the sky just kept getting better and better.\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0In a high contrast scene like this, I always bracket my exposures by as much as 3 stops overexposed to 3 stops under exposed. It is best to use a tripod when bracketing images in this matter, but not absolutely required.\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0Bracketing like this ensures the dynamic range of the image is captured well on the camera sensor. Later in post processing the 5-7 bracketed images, are blended together into a single HDR image, thus ensuring detail even in the darkest shadows and brightest highlights.\xc2\xa0\xc2\xa0My goal with HDR, is to render the scene the way I saw it, not for any special effect." \xe2\x80\xa2
\xe2\x80\xa2
Camera: #Canon 5D Mark IV 
Lens: EF 24-70 f/2.8 II USM
Aperture: f/10
ISO: 100
Shutter Speed: 1/8 sec
Focal Length: 45mm'

b'Photo by #CanonExplorerOfLight @adam_jones_photo | "This paper kite butterfly is a large tree nymph butterfly, native to Southeast Asia and Northern Australia. This large butterfly is a very popular butterfly in butterfly houses. This beauty was filmed in Butterfly World, Coconut Creek, FL. Tripods are not allowed so this was a hand held image with a bit of fill flash.  The key here is having enough shutter speed to hand hold a 100-400 IS II lens at minimum focus, and have enough depth of field to ensure the subject is sharp all around. The camera should be perfectly square with the plane of the butterfly wing to ensure adequate sharpness from top to bottom. Fill flash was set at minus 2 stops below the ambient light. This setting on a cloudy day reduces some of the darker shadow areas, and does not look flashed. I look for subjects I can square with, and are quite a bit in front of their background. This yields a soft natural looking background that is not distracting." Camera: #Canon EOS IDX Mark III
Lens: EOS 100-400 IS II at 300mm with Extension Tube EF 25 II
Aperture: f/9
ISO: 2500
Shutter Speed: 1/400 sec'

b'\xe2\x80\x9cNauset Light is an iconic Cape Cod lighthouse, located in the town of Eastham near Coastguard Beach along the National Seashore. After arrival on location at about 10 pm, I immediately started scouting for an interesting composition of the lighthouse. After a few test shots at high ISO settings to finalize focus and composition, I dialed in my initial camera settings. While patiently waiting for the milky way to rise into the desired position I took multiple test shots, making adjustments and working my way towards the final settings. Blowing out the night sky milky way and the bright fresnel was a major concern, so I used a piece of paper that I positioned in front of my lens periodically during the long exposure time. This allowed less light in certain areas of the night sky and for more contrast between sky and milky way. Good light and happy photo making!\xe2\x80\x9d #MyCanonStory 
Photo Credit: @RothGalleries
Camera: #Canon EOS 5D Mark IV
Lens: EF 16-35mm f/2.8L III USM
Aperture: f/2.8
ISO: 1600
Shutter Speed: 25 sec
Focal Length: 16mm'

b'"Family trip to Sefa-utak, Japan. b'Congratulations to #CanonExplorerOfLight @stephsinclairpix on her photo being selected for National Geographic's "Best of the Decade" gallery. | "Every 2 seconds a girl is married, impacting some 12 million girls each year. This portrait of Yemeni child brides Ghada and Tahani - with their adult husbands - was part of a June 2011 National Geographic article and then prominently featured in a global United Nations anti-child-marriage campaign spanning more than 25 countries. The UN and the US now define protection from coerced early marriage as a basic human right. These beautiful young girls are also among the many who inspired me to found the charitable organization @tooyoungtowed, whose mission is to empower girls and end child marriage globally." For more culture and human rights stories, follow @stephsinclairpix.

b'"Standing in front of one of the largest tide pools I have ever seen, I saw the crashing waves stirring up the sea foam in the pool and swirling it around. As the tide pool kept expanding and contracting with the tide, I chased the edge of the pool to make several long exposures with the intention of capturing the dynamic movement of the floating sea foam. I created the end result by blending three exposures. On top of the base image containing the central swirl, one exposure was necessary to recover the blown out sky and the other contained sharper foam swirls in the foreground." #MyCanonStory

Photo Credit: @imaginairemedia
Camera: #Canon EOS 6D Mark II

Aperture: f/10
ISO: 50
Shutter Speed: 30 sec
Focal Length:  16mm'

b"Photo by @babaktafreshi |\xe2\x80\x9dTesting out the new astrophotography #EOSRa that Canon lent me. In two decades of nightscape photography I used variety of film and digital cameras. I remember the first #Canon astro-camera 20Da in 2005 and then 60Da in 2012. On my recent trip to New Zealand, under the magnificent southern sky I was testing the new EOS Ra which is both a full frame and ultralight mirrorless. On this evening, on a bird preserved lake 10 miles from Whanganui, the galactic core of the Milky Way in constellations Scorpius and Sagittarius was setting. The parting low clouds, lit by the town, suddenly formed a colorful halo around bright planet Jupiter, while a car headlight on a nearby road created striking rays through a line of eucalyptus trees across the lake. Since I was doing a continuous time-lapse sequence, and using a remote shutter switch, I didn't miss this unique moment.\xe2\x80\x9d
#eosra #astrophotography #nightscape #milkyway 
Camera: #Canon EOS Ra
Lens: RF 15-35mm F2.8L IS USM
Aperture: f/2.8
ISO: 12800
Shutter Speed: 8 sec
Focal Length: 24mm"
